questionOriginal: Does cooking food kill COVID-19?
questionText: Does cooking food kill COVID-19?
answerOriginal: Current thinking is that COVID-19 mostly spreads from person to person through respiratory droplets. There is currently no evidence that it can be spread through food. In general, you should practice good hygiene and food safety practices. This means cleaning surfaces that are used a lot, cleaning your fruits and vegetables, and cooking meats well. Wash your hands with soap and water before handling food.
answerText: Current thinking is that COVID-19 mostly spreads from person to person through respiratory droplets. There is currently no evidence that it can be spread through food. In general, you should practice good hygiene and food safety practices. This means cleaning surfaces that are used a lot, cleaning your fruits and vegetables, and cooking meats well. Wash your hands with soap and water before handling food.

questionOriginal: If my pet has been exposed to someone who has COVID-19, do they need to be quarantined? If so, for how long?
questionText: If my pet has been exposed to someone who has COVID-19, do they need to be quarantined? If so, for how long?
answerOriginal: There is no evidence that pets can get sick from COVID-19. You may wish to keep distance your pet for the same amount of time as people are being asked to keep distance - 14 days.
answerText: You may wish to keep distance your pet for the same amount of time as people are being asked to keep distance - 14 days. Treat pets as you would other human family members – do not let pets interact with people or animals outside the household. If a person inside the household becomes sick, isolate that person from everyone else, including pets.

questionOriginal: What is the difference between a bacteria and a virus?
questionText: What is the difference between a bacteria and a virus?
answerOriginal: The main differences between viruses and bacteria are:  1. Viruses need to infect other cells to reproduce. They can't reproduce on their own. However, bacteria can reproduce on their own. 2. Viruses usually can't survive on their own as long as bacteria. 3. Viruses are much smaller than bacteria. 4. Most viruses cause disease. Some bacteria cause disease and some do not. 5. Viruses are usually more specific than bacteria about the kinds of cells that they attack in the body. For example, the virus that causes COVID-19 mostly affects cells in the respiratory system (the parts of the body involved in breathing)  [[Would you like more information about What is a virus?]]
answerText: An N95 respirator is a special type of mask that filters very small particles in the air. You need to get a fit test to make sure that the mask fits well and works. The "N95" means that the respirator blocks at least 95 percent of very small (0.3 micron) particles when tested.  It is not recommended that the general public wear  N95 masks at this time. That is because there are not enough of these masks for health care workers. Health care workers need these masks to stay safe and to take care of sick patients. If you have extra N95 masks, please donate them to your local healthcare facility.   [[Would you like more information about Should I wear a mask?]] [[Would you like more information about Can we use fabric masks to prevent the spread?]]

questionOriginal: Should I stay home and even avoid going to the supermarket and drugstore?
questionText: Should I stay home and even avoid going to the supermarket and drugstore?
answerOriginal: Yes, you can go to the supermarket and drugstore whenever absolutely necessary, but it is important to go during off-peak hours when less people will be there. It is also important to go as few times as possible to these locations so try and make a thorough list ahead of time so you do not forget any supplies.
answerText: If you believe you have been exposed to COVID-19, or if you are at high risk of symptoms, you should not go to the grocery store. Depending on where you traveled to, your local or national government may recommend that you stay quarantine for a period after recent travel. If you do go to the grocery store, continue to distance yourself as much as possible from other customers, avoid touching your face while outside, and wash your hands as soon as you come home. Some areas require you to wear a mask when going outdoors such as a to the grocery store.

questionOriginal: What types of jobs or workplaces are considered essential during the shelter in place order?
questionText: What types of jobs or workplaces are considered essential during the shelter in place order?
answerOriginal: Businesses will be required to hold in-person operations:  • Workers should not leave their homes. Only workers who work in essential services can leave. • Businesses decide who meet these criteria  • Businesses that remain open must take protective measures  • Examples of jobs or workplaces allowed remaining open include:  • grocery stores • hospitals and mobile emergency units • doctor’s offices  • utility companies • law enforcement • banks and credit unions • gas stations
answerText: Essential businesses are business that will be required to hold in-person operations:  •        Businesses and government agencies decide who is considered essential.  •        Businesses that remain open must take protective measures  •        Examples of jobs or workplaces allowed remaining open include:  •        grocery stores •        hospitals and mobile emergency units •        doctor’s offices  •        utility companies •        law enforcement •        banks and credit unions •        gas stations

questionOriginal: Does being able to hold your breath for 10 seconds or more without coughing or feeling discomfot mean you are free from the coronavirus disease (COVID-19) or any other lung disease?
questionText: Does being able to hold your breath for 10 seconds or more without coughing or feeling discomfot mean you are free from the coronavirus disease (COVID-19) or any other lung disease?
answerOriginal: No. The most common symptoms of COVID-19 are dry cough, tiredness and fever. Some people may develop more severe forms of the disease, such as pneumonia. The best way to confirm if you have  the virus producing COVID-19 disease is with a laboratory test.  You cannot confirm it with this breathing exercise, which can even be dangerous.
answerText: No, being able to hold your breath without coughing or discomfort does not tell you whether you have COVID-19 or not. The best way to confirm if you have  the virus producing COVID-19 disease is with a laboratory test.  You cannot confirm it with this breathing exercise, which can even be dangerous. If you are concerned you may have been infected, contact your healthcare provider to get tested.

questionOriginal: Can you recover from the coronavirus disease (COVID-19)?
questionText: Can you recover from the coronavirus disease (COVID-19)?
answerOriginal: Catching the new coronavirus DOES NOT mean you will have it for life. Most of the people who catch COVID-19 can recover and eliminate the virus from their bodies. If you catch the disease, make sure you treat your symptoms. If you have cough, fever, and difficulty breathing, seek medical care early – but call your health facility by telephone first. Most patients recover thanks to supportive care.
answerText: Catching the new coronavirus DOES NOT mean you will have it for life. Most of the people who catch COVID-19 can recover and eliminate the virus from their bodies. If you catch the disease, make sure you treat your symptoms. If you have difficulty breathing, shortness of breath or any other concerns, seek medical care early and go to your local emergency room in case of emergency. Most people are able to recover at home from COVID-19.

topic: COVID-19 How to Protect Yourself / Your Family / Your Community
questionOriginal: What are ways to manage anxiety about Coronavirus?
questionText: What are ways to manage anxiety about Coronavirus?
answerOriginal: Get your facts straight. It’s important to stay up-to-date with the latest news from trusted sources regarding COVID-19. Be careful about what you read on the internet, especially comments and articles that are being shared via social media.   Keep things in perspective. Although you’ll want to stay informed about COVID-19, it’s important to focus on what you can control. Take a break from media coverage or social media if you find yourself panicking about the news or an article you just read online. If talking endlessly about coronavirus is upsetting to you, change the topic of conversation when you can. Be mindful and self-aware. Not everyone you come in contact with has been exposed to COVID-19. Although caution and preventative measures are extremely important right now, not everyone who coughs has the virus. Being self-aware is a big component of easing public anxiety. Focus on what you can do. Try to keep some normalcy. It can be hard with trips and events being cancelled, schools being closed and the concept of “social distancing” always at the top of your mind. But it’s important to try to maintain some sort of schedule. Routine makes most people, especially children, feel safe. Try to keep your normal sleep and meal times and focus on activities that make you feel happy – like reading a book, watching your favorite show or playing a board game with your family. Or take a walk, as long as you’re not in quarantine, a little fresh air is always a good idea!
answerText: 1) Get your facts straight. It’s important to stay up-to-date with the latest news from trusted sources regarding COVID-19. Be careful about what you read on the internet, especially comments and articles that are being shared via social media.   2) Keep things in perspective. Although you’ll want to stay informed about COVID-19, it’s important to focus on what you can control. Take a break from media coverage or social media if you find yourself panicking about the news or an article you just read online. If talking endlessly about coronavirus is upsetting to you, change the topic of conversation when you can. 3) Be mindful and self-aware. Being self-aware of your feelings is a big component of easing public anxiety. Focus on what you can do. 4) Try to keep some normalcy. It is important to try to maintain some sort of schedule. Routine makes most people, especially children, feel safe. Try to keep your normal sleep and meal times and focus on activities that make you feel happy – like reading a book, watching your favorite show or playing a board game with your family. Or take a walk, as long as you’re not in quarantine, a little fresh air is always a good idea! 5) Stay connected with family and friends through video chats and phone calls.

questionOriginal: What are the general recommendatiosn for routine cleaning and disinfection of households with People Isolated in Home Care (e.g. Suspected/Confirmed to have COVID-19)?
questionText: What are the general recommendatiosn for routine cleaning and disinfection of households with People Isolated in Home Care (e.g. Suspected/Confirmed to have COVID-19)?
answerOriginal: Family members should educate themselves about COVID-19 symptoms and preventing the spread of COVID-19 in homes. Clean and disinfect high touch surfaces daily in common areas (e.g. tables, chairs, doorknobs, light switches, phones, tablets, touch screens, remote controls, keyboards, handles, desks, toilets, sinks) In the bedroom and bathroom for an ill person: consider only cleaning their room as-needed (e.g., soiled items and surfaces) to avoid unnecessary contact with the ill person. As much as possible, an ill person should stay in a specific room and away from other people in their home. The caregiver can provide personal cleaning supplies for an ill person’s room and bathroom, unless the room is occupied by child or another person for whom such supplies would not be right. These supplies include tissues, paper towels and cleaners. If a separate bathroom is not available, the bathroom should be cleaned and disinfected after each use by an ill person. If this is not possible, the caregiver should wait as long as possible after use by an ill person to clean and disinfect the high touch surfaces.
answerText: Family members should learn about COVID-19 symptoms and how to prevent the spread of COVID-19 in homes. Here are some tips:  1. Clean and disinfect high touch surfaces daily in common areas (e.g. tables, chairs, doorknobs, light switches, phones, tablets, touch screens, remote controls, keyboards, handles, desks, toilets, sinks). If possible, the person with the infection should stay in a different room and away from other people in the home. In the bedroom and bathroom for an ill person: consider only cleaning their room as-needed (e.g., soiled items and surfaces) to avoid unnecessary contact with the ill person. If the person who is sick is old enough (e.g. not a child or someone else who could not responsibly and safely use cleeaning supplies), the caregiver can provide personal cleaning supplies for them to clean their own room and bathroom. These supplies include tissues, paper towels and cleaners. If a separate bathroom is not available, the bathroom should be cleaned and disinfected after each use by an ill person. If this is not possible, the caregiver should wait as long as possible after use by an ill person to clean and disinfect the high touch surfaces.

questionOriginal: Where can I buy hand sanitizer?
questionText: Where can I buy hand sanitizer?
answerOriginal: Many stores and pharmacies sell hand sanitizers. We understand that many stores have run out of hand sanitizers and they may be hard to find. It is not recommended to buy homemade hand sanitizer from friends or other non-approved sources.
answerText: Many stores and pharmacies sell hand sanitizers, although some stores may have run out. Make sure to get a hand sanitizer that is at least 60% alcohol. It is not recommended to buy homemade hand sanitizer from friends or other non-approved sources.  [[Would you like more information about Should I use soap and water or a hand sanitizer to protect against COVID-19?]]

questionOriginal: Are there enough tests for COVID-19?
questionText: Are there enough tests for COVID-19?
answerOriginal: Some areas may currently be experiencing a shortage of COVID-19 tests. If you suspect you have been exposed to COVID-19 or that you may have COVID-19, you should contact your health care provider to determine if a test is recommended. In the meantime, even if you are not tested, you should stay at home and self-isolate or self-monitor.  [[Would you like to hear more about What's the difference between self-isolating and self-monitoring?]]
answerText: Some areas may not have enough COVID-19 tests. If you think you have been exposed to COVID-19 or that you may have COVID-19, contact your health care provider to find out if you need a test. Even if you are not tested, you should stay at home and self-isolate or self-monitor to protect yourself and others around you.   [[Would you like more information about What's the difference between self-isolating and self-monitoring?]] [[Would you like more information about What are COVID-19 symptoms?]]

questionOriginal: Are there any approved products that can prevent or treat COVID-19 in animals?
questionText: Are there any approved products that can prevent or treat COVID-19 in animals?
answerOriginal: Animals are not likely to get COVID-19.
answerText: There are no recommended products to prevent or treat animals from getting sick. Treat pets as you would other human family members – do not let pets interact with people or animals outside the household. If a person inside the household becomes sick, isolate that person from everyone else, including pets.

questionOriginal: What does it mean if someone is being monitored for COVID-19?
questionText: What does it mean if someone is being monitored for COVID-19?
answerOriginal: Public health monitors the health of people who could have been exposed to the virus.  Local health department staff contact the individual, assess their risk and supervise daily for health monitoring (temperature, cough, difficulty breathing) for 14 days after their last day of exposure.
answerText: Monitoring for COVID-19 means looking for signs of illness in people who could have been exposed to COVID-19. Sometimes a doctor or a health department may monitor a patient for symptoms. If it is a health department doing the monitoring, staff members may contact the person, assess their risk, and check in frequently about symptoms for 14 days after the day they were exposed.  [[Would you like more information about What is self-monitoring?]] [[Would you like more information about What are COVID-19 symptoms?]]

questionOriginal: What should people do if they think they may have been infected?
questionText: What should people do if they think they may have been infected?
answerOriginal: People who think they may have been exposed should call a health care professional if they have any of the symptoms.
answerText: If you think you were exposed to COVID-19, call a health care professional to find out if you need to be tested or if there is anything else you should do for your health. If you think you have been infected, you should self-quarantine so you do not get anyone else sick.  [[Would you like more information about What is self-quarantine?]] [[Would you like more information about What are COVID-19 symptoms?]]

questionOriginal: Do vaccines against pneumonia protect you against the new coronavirus?
questionText: Do vaccines against pneumonia protect you against the new coronavirus?
answerOriginal: Vaccines against pneumonia do not provide protection against the new coronavirus. The virus is so new and different that it needs its own vaccine. Vaccines against respiratory illnesses are highly recommended to protect your health.
answerText: Different types of viruses and bacteria can cause pneumonia. The virus that causes COVID-19 is a new type and needs its own vaccine. So, if you had a different vaccine that protects against some types of pneumonia, it will not protect you against pneumonia caused by the new coronavirus. You should continue to get routine vaccines that your doctor recommends.  [[Would you like more information about How can I protect myself and others?]]

questionOriginal: Will Miracle Mineral Solution (MMS) cure COVID-19?
questionText: Will Miracle Mineral Solution (MMS) cure COVID-19?
answerOriginal: Antibiotics like Miracle Mineral Solution (MM) do not work against viruses and they only work on bacterial infections.
answerText: Miracle Mineral Solution (MMS) is an industrial bleach. You should not drink it. It has harmful side effects and it is not an approved treatment for diseases caused by viruses.  [[Would you like more information about How can I protect myself and others?]]

questionOriginal: Why is convalescent plasma being investigated to treat COVID-19?
questionText: Why is convalescent plasma being investigated to treat COVID-19?
answerOriginal: Convalescent plasma is being tested because there is no approved treatment for COVID-19 and there is some information that it might help some patients get better from COVID-19. More research is needed to see if it helps patients.
answerText: Convalescent plasma is being tested as a treatment for COVID-19 because there is no approved treatment right now. There are some reports that it might help some high risk patients get better from COVID-19. More research is needed to see if it helps patients.  [[Would you like more information about What is convalescent plasma?]]

questionOriginal: What is convalescent plasma?
questionText: What is convalescent plasma?
answerOriginal: Convalescent plasma is the liquid part of blood that is taken from patients who are no longer sick.  [[Would you like more information about Why is convalescent plasma being investigated to treat COVID-19?]]
answerText: Convalescent plasma is the liquid part of blood that comes from people who have gotten better from COVID-19. Convalescent plasma contains proteins that might help the infection. These proteins are called antibodies.  [[Would you like more information about Why is convalescent plasma being investigated to treat COVID-19?]]

questionOriginal: How can I help make sure people who are vulnerable get access to food?
questionText: How can I help make sure people who are vulnerable get access to food?
answerOriginal: Consider buying only what you need at the grocery store so that others in the community can access supplies they need. If you do have financial resources to contribute to the COVID-19 response, consider donating to food bank networks.
answerText: Buy only what you need at the grocery store so that others in your community can get the supplies they need. If you can contribute to the COVID-19 response, consider donating money or food to food bank networks.  [[Would you like more information about How can I help others?]]

questionOriginal: Can COVID-19 live in your refrigerator?
questionText: Can COVID-19 live in your refrigerator?
answerOriginal: It may be possible that a person can get COVID-19 by touching a surface or object, like a piece of food or a packaging container, that has the virus on it and then touching their own mouth, nose, or possibly their eyes. This is not the main way the virus spreads. There is low risk of spreading coronavirus from food products or packaging.  Currently, there is no evidence to support transmission of COVID-19 associated with food. Before preparing or eating food it is important to always wash your hands with soap and water for at least 20 seconds for general food safety.
answerText: It may be possible that a person can get COVID-19 by touching a surface or object, like a piece of food or a packaging container, that has the virus on it and then touching their own mouth, nose, or possibly their eyes. This is not the main way the virus spreads. There is low risk of spreading coronavirus from food products or packaging.  Currently, there is no evidence to support transmission of COVID-19 associated with food. Before preparing or eating food it is important to always wash your hands with soap and water for at least 20 seconds for general food safety.

questionOriginal: Can COVID-19 in cats be treated?
questionText: Can COVID-19 in cats be treated?
answerOriginal: As of April 2020, there is no evidence that pets (such as cats or dogs) can spread COVID-19. If you have questions about the health of your pet you should contact your veterinarian.
answerText: If you are concerned that your pet is ill, contact your pet's veternarian to learn the latest information on transmission to pets

questionOriginal: What precautions should I take if I am going to the hospital for delivery?
questionText: What precautions should I take if I am going to the hospital for delivery?
answerOriginal: The hospital will ensure that everything is cleaned and sanitized for your stay and delivery. No, you do not have to bring your pillow and sheets for the hospital bed. However, it is important that you are aware of certain policies hospitals are beginning to administer. For example, some hospitals are not allowing any visitors - which means your loved one, doula, etc will not be able to be beside you as you give birth. Please call your healthcare provider to get more information.   [[Would you like more information about what do I do if I've tested positive for COVID-19 and am about to deliver?]]
answerText: If you are pregnant, here are some steps you can take to stay healthy:  1.        Wash your hands. You’ve heard this advice over and over. But that’s because it works! Keeping hands clean can stop the virus in its tracks. 2.        Practice “social distancing.” Stay away from other people and large groups. If you need to be around others, try to keep 6 feet (2 meters) away. 3.        Get the flu shot. It won’t protect you against COVID-19. But it will lower your risk of getting the flu since the flu can also cause problems for pregnant moms. 4.        Go virtual. Try to have virtual (online) or phone visits with your doctor whenever you can. Spending less time in the waiting room and office can help you stay healthy. However, you might still need an in-person visit for some things like ultrasounds or blood work. 5.        Call your doctor if you’re coughing. If you have symptoms like cough, fever, or shortness of breath, call or email your doctor. They will decide if you should be tested for COVID-19 and tell you what to do next.  [[Would you like more information about What is social distancing?]]  [[Would you like more information about What are COVID-19 symptoms?]]  [[Would you like more information about What precautions should I take if I am going to the hospital for delivery?]]

questionOriginal: Will the grocery stores close down?
questionText: Will the grocery stores close down?
answerOriginal: Grocery stores are considered essential businesses and are not likely to close.
answerText: Grocery stores are considered essential businesses and are not likely to close.

questionOriginal: Do health workers know how to take samples correctly from patients?
questionText: Do health workers know how to take samples correctly from patients?
answerOriginal: Yes. Sample collection for COVID-19 is similar to procedures that hospitals and healthcare workers follow for respiratory viruses. Laboratories have developed kits and guidance to ensure proper collection and shipping of samples.
answerText: Taking a sample for COVID-19 is very similar to how healthcare workers take samples for flu and other respiratory illnesses. Laboratories have made kits that make it easy to collect and ship samples.  [[Would you like more information about Should I get tested for COVID-19?]]

questionOriginal: Do animals get their own type of coronaviruses?
questionText: Do animals get their own type of coronaviruses?
answerOriginal: Some types of coronaviruses cause flu-like sickness in humans, while others cause sickness in some types of animals.
answerText: Yes, there are some viruses that cause illnesses just in animals.

questionOriginal: Does COVID-19 have a different impact on women in their first trimester as opposed to their second or third trimester?
questionText: Does COVID-19 have a different impact on women in their first trimester as opposed to their second or third trimester?
answerOriginal: Unfortunately, we do not know. High fevers in early pregnancy generally can increase the risk of birth defects, but the effect of COVID-19 on women and their developing babies in early pregnancy is still unclear. There is so much that is unknown about how COVID-19  affects pregnancy.
answerText: Unfortunately, we do not know yet if there are different effects of COVID-19 during different trimesters and more research is needed to understand what effects the virus has. If you have specific concerns, talk to your obstetrics provider to learn more and to stay up to date on the latest research.

questionOriginal: If my pet has been vaccinated for a species-specific cornavirus, does that make them more or less likely to get COVID-19?
questionText: If my pet has been vaccinated for a species-specific cornavirus, does that make them more or less likely to get COVID-19?
answerOriginal: There have been no reports of pets or other animals becoming sick with COVID-19 as of now.  There is no data to suggest that another strain of coronavirus would cause your pet to get COVID-19.
answerText: It is hard to predict whether a pet who has had one type of vaccine is more or less susceptible to a new virus. The best course of action is to treat pets as you would other human family members – do not let pets interact with people or animals outside the household. If a person inside the household becomes sick, isolate that person from everyone else, including pets.

questionOriginal: How long does COVID-19 last on fruits and vegetables?
questionText: How long does COVID-19 last on fruits and vegetables?
answerOriginal: Right now there is no evidence that the virus can be spread through food or food packaging. However, since COVID-19 can live on surfaces for up to 72 hours, if you are worried you can disinfect food packaging after bringing it home from the store. You should also follow the usual food safety steps like washing hands with soap and water before and after preparing food, and following the Food and Drug Administration’s (FDA) four food safety steps: clean, separate, cook, and chill.  [[Would you like more information about how long COVID-19 lives on surfaces?]]
answerText: Right now there is no evidence that the virus can be spread through food or food packaging. However, since COVID-19 can live on surfaces for up to 72 hours, if you are worried you can disinfect food packaging after bringing it home from the store. You should also follow the usual food safety steps like washing hands with soap and water before and after preparing food, and following the Food and Drug Administration’s (FDA) four food safety steps: clean, separate, cook, and chill.  [[Would you like more information about how long COVID-19 lives on surfaces?]]

questionOriginal: Is it alright for health facilities to accept free supplies of formula milk for infants of mothers with confirmed/suspected COVID-19?
questionText: Is it alright for health facilities to accept free supplies of formula milk for infants of mothers with confirmed/suspected COVID-19?
answerOriginal: Donations of infant formula milks should not be accepted.
answerText: Donations of infant formula milks should not be accepted.

questionOriginal: Why do recommendations for mothers with confirmed or suspected COVID-19 and their infants seem different from social distancing recommendations for the general population?
questionText: Why do recommendations for mothers with confirmed or suspected COVID-19 and their infants seem different from social distancing recommendations for the general population?
answerOriginal: The recommendations for adults and older children to maintain social distancing are to reduce contact with persons not showing symptoms who have COVID-19 so that the virus does not spread. The recommendations for babies and young children whose mothers have confirmed or suspected COVID-19 infection is to improve the survival, health and development of their newborns and infants.
answerText: The recommendations for adults and older children to maintain social distancing are to reduce contact with persons not showing symptoms who have COVID-19 so that the virus does not spread. The recommendations for babies and young children whose mothers have confirmed or suspected COVID-19 infection is to improve the survival, health and development of their newborns and infants.

questionOriginal: If a mother is confirmed or suspected to have COVID-19, is infant formula milk safer for infants?
questionText: If a mother is confirmed or suspected to have COVID-19, is infant formula milk safer for infants?
answerOriginal: There are always risks associated with giving infant formula milk to newborns and infants in all settings. The risks associated with giving infant formula milk are increased whenever home and community conditions are affected. The numerous benefits of breastfeeding significantly outweigh the potential risks of transmission and illness that occur with the COVID-19 virus.
answerText: There are always risks associated with giving infant formula milk to newborns and infants in all settings. The risks associated with giving infant formula milk are increased whenever home and community conditions are affected. The numerous benefits of breastfeeding significantly outweigh the potential risks of transmission and illness that occur with the COVID-19 virus.

questionOriginal: What are key messages for a mother who wants to breastfeed but is scared about passing COVID-19 to her infant?
questionText: What are key messages for a mother who wants to breastfeed but is scared about passing COVID-19 to her infant?
answerOriginal: As part of counseling, a mother’s anxiety about COVID-19 should be acknowledged and responded to with the following messages: - COVID-19 has not been detected in the breastmilk of any mother with confirmed or suspected COVID-19 and there is no evidence so far that the virus is transmitted through breastfeeding. - Newborns and infants are at low risk of COVID-19 infection.  - Breastfeeding and skin-to-skin contact reduces the risk of death in newborns and young infants and provide lifelong health and development benefits. Breastfeeding also reduces the risk of breast and ovarian cancer for the mother.
answerText: As part of counseling, a mother’s anxiety about COVID-19 should be acknowledged and responded to with the following messages: - COVID-19 has not been detected in the breastmilk of any mother with confirmed or suspected COVID-19 and there is no evidence so far that the virus is transmitted through breastfeeding. - Newborns and infants are at low risk of COVID-19 infection.  - Breastfeeding and skin-to-skin contact reduces the risk of death in newborns and young infants and provide lifelong health and development benefits. Breastfeeding also reduces the risk of breast and ovarian cancer for the mother.

questionOriginal: Is it advisable for a mother with confirmed or suspected COVID-19 who is breastfeeding, to give a ‘top-up’ with infant formula milk?
questionText: Is it advisable for a mother with confirmed or suspected COVID-19 who is breastfeeding, to give a ‘top-up’ with infant formula milk?
answerOriginal: If a mother is confirmed or suspected to have COVID-19 and is breastfeeding, there is no need to provide a top up with an infant formula milk. Giving a top up will reduce the amount of milk given by a mother. Mothers who breastfeed should be counseled and supported to ensure positioning and attachment gives adequate milk production.
answerText: If a mother is confirmed or suspected to have COVID-19 and is breastfeeding, there is no need to provide a top up with an infant formula milk. Giving a top up will reduce the amount of milk given by a mother. Mothers who breastfeed should be counseled and supported to ensure positioning and attachment gives adequate milk production.

questionOriginal: If my pet previously had a species-specific coronavirus, does that make them more or less likely to get COVID-19?
questionText: If my pet previously had a species-specific coronavirus, does that make them more or less likely to get COVID-19?
answerOriginal: There have been no reports of pets or other animals becoming sick with COVID-19 as of now.  There is no data to suggest that another strain of coronavirus would cause your pet to get COVID-19.
answerText: It is hard to predict whether a pet who has had one type of virus is more or less susceptible to a new virus. The best course of action is to treat pets as you would other human family members – do not let pets interact with people or animals outside the household. If a person inside the household becomes sick, isolate that person from everyone else, including pets.

questionOriginal: If a mother confirmed/suspected to have COVID-19 was unable to breastfeed because she was too ill or because of another illness, when can she start to breastfeed again?
questionText: If a mother confirmed/suspected to have COVID-19 was unable to breastfeed because she was too ill or because of another illness, when can she start to breastfeed again?
answerOriginal: A mother can start to breastfeed when she feels well enough to do so. There is no fixed time interval to wait after confirmed/suspected COVID-19. There is no evidence that breastfeeding changes the clinical course of COVID-19 in a mother. She should be supported in her general health and nutrition to ensure full recovery. She should also be supported to initiate breastfeeding or relactate.
answerText: A mother can start to breastfeed when she feels well enough to do so. There is no fixed time interval to wait after confirmed/suspected COVID-19. There is no evidence that breastfeeding changes the clinical course of COVID-19 in a mother. She should be supported in her general health and nutrition to ensure full recovery. She should also be supported to initiate breastfeeding or relactate.

questionOriginal: What caused COVID-19?
questionText: What caused COVID-19?
answerOriginal: The COVID-19 pandemic was caused by a new type of coronavirus that recently spread from animals to people. The name of the virus that caused the COVID-19 pandemic is called "SARS-CoV-2".  [[Would you like more information about What is SARS-CoV-2?]] [[Would you like more information about What is MERs-CoV?]] [[Would you like more information about What is SARS-CoV?]] [[Would you like more information about What is a coronavirus?]]
answerText: All blood donors are required to be in good health and have a normal body temperature on the day of donation. People with COVID-19 will not be allowed to donate blood.  Donors are told to contact the donor center if they become sick after donation, so that their donation will not be used.

questionOriginal: If a mother with confirmed/suspected COVID-19 is not able to breastfeed or to express breastmilk, can wet-nursing be recommended?
questionText: If a mother with confirmed/suspected COVID-19 is not able to breastfeed or to express breastmilk, can wet-nursing be recommended?
answerOriginal: Wet-nursing may be an option depending on acceptability to mothers/families, national guidelines, cultural acceptability, availability of wet-nurses and services to support mothers and wet nurses. • In settings where HIV is common, wet nurses should undergo HIV counseling and rapid testing where available. In the absence of testing, if feasible undertake HIV risk assessment. If HIV risk assessment or counseling is not possible, continue with wet nursing.  • Prioritize wet nurses for the youngest infants.
answerText: Wet-nursing may be an option depending on acceptability to mothers/families, national guidelines, cultural acceptability, availability of wet-nurses and services to support mothers and wet nurses. • In settings where HIV is common, wet nurses should undergo HIV counseling and rapid testing where available. In the absence of testing, if feasible undertake HIV risk assessment. If HIV risk assessment or counseling is not possible, continue with wet nursing.  • Prioritize wet nurses for the youngest infants.

questionOriginal: If a mother with confirmed/suspected COVID-19 is expressing her milk for her baby, are there extra measures needed when handling the breastmilk pump, milk storage containers or feeding utensils?
questionText: If a mother with confirmed/suspected COVID-19 is expressing her milk for her baby, are there extra measures needed when handling the breastmilk pump, milk storage containers or feeding utensils?
answerOriginal: Even when COVID-19 is not a consideration, breastmilk pumps, milk storage containers and feeding utensils need to be appropriately cleaned after every use. • Wash the pump/containers after every use with liquid soap, e.g. dishwashing liquid and warm water. Rinse after with hot water for 10-15 seconds. • Some breast pumps parts can be put in the top rack of a dishwasher (if available). Check the instruction manual before doing this.
answerText: Even when COVID-19 is not a consideration, breastmilk pumps, milk storage containers and feeding utensils need to be appropriately cleaned after every use. • Wash the pump/containers after every use with liquid soap, e.g. dishwashing liquid and warm water. Rinse after with hot water for 10-15 seconds. • Some breast pumps parts can be put in the top rack of a dishwasher (if available). Check the instruction manual before doing this.

questionOriginal: Do the results of COVID-19 testing make any difference to infant and young child feeding recommendations?
questionText: Do the results of COVID-19 testing make any difference to infant and young child feeding recommendations?
answerOriginal: COVID-19 testing does not have any immediate connection for decisions on infant and young child feeding. However, confirmation of COVID-19 means that a mother should start appropriate recommended hygiene practices for the period that she is likely to be infective i.e. while symptomatic or through the 14 days after the start of symptoms, whichever is longer.
answerText: COVID-19 testing does not have any immediate connection for decisions on infant and young child feeding. However, confirmation of COVID-19 means that a mother should start appropriate recommended hygiene practices for the period that she is likely to be infective i.e. while symptomatic or through the 14 days after the start of symptoms, whichever is longer.

questionOriginal: Is it necessary for a mother with confirmed or suspected COVID-19 to wash her breast before she breastfeeds directly or before expressing milk?
questionText: Is it necessary for a mother with confirmed or suspected COVID-19 to wash her breast before she breastfeeds directly or before expressing milk?
answerOriginal: She should gently wash the breast with soap and warm water for at least 20 seconds prior to feeding. It is not necessary to wash the breast before every breastfeed or prior to expressing milk if the mother has not been exposed to COVID-19.
answerText: She should gently wash the breast with soap and warm water for at least 20 seconds prior to feeding. It is not necessary to wash the breast before every breastfeed or prior to expressing milk if the mother has not been exposed to COVID-19.

questionOriginal: Is the U.S. animal food supply safe?
questionText: Is the U.S. animal food supply safe?
answerOriginal: Currently there is no evidence of animal food or food packaging causing COVID-19.  SARS-CoV-2, which causes COVID-19, is a virus that causes respiratory illness. Foodborne exposure to this virus is not known to be a route of transmission.
answerText: Currently there is no evidence of animal food or food packaging causing COVID-19.It is important to maintain general hand hygiene and wash hands frequently while preparing food.

questionOriginal: Will there be food shortages?
questionText: Will there be food shortages?
answerOriginal: There are no nationwide shortages of food, although in some cases certain foods at your grocery store might be low sometimes before stores can restock. Food production and manufacturing are throughout the U.S. and there are currently no disruptions reported in the supply chain. FDA is closely monitoring the food supply chain for any shortages in collaboration with industry and our federal and state partners.
answerText: There are no nationwide shortages of food at this time, although in some cases certain foods at your grocery store might be low sometimes before stores can restock.  National organizations such as the Food and Drug Administration in the U.S. is closely monitoring the food supply chain for any shortages in collaboration with industry and our federal and state partners. Check with your national agency to stay up to date on shortages in your country.

questionOriginal: Why are blood centers not testing donors for SARS-CoV-2 in the United States?
questionText: Why are blood centers not testing donors for SARS-CoV-2 in the United States?
answerOriginal: Someone who has symptoms of COVID-19 is not healthy enough to donate blood. The screening processes already in place will mean that someone with these symptoms will not be allowed to donate.
answerText: Someone who has symptoms of COVID-19 is not healthy enough to donate blood. Every blood donation center has a different protocol and testing may not always be possible due to testing shortages. Most centers have screening processes in place will mean that someone with active symptoms or recent exposure will not be allowed to donate.

questionOriginal: Can COVID-19 be passed through breastfeeding?
questionText: Can COVID-19 be passed through breastfeeding?
answerOriginal: The COVID-19 virus has not been seen in the breastmilk of any mother with confirmed or suspected cases. Researchers continue to test breastmilk from mothers with confirmed or suspected cases.
answerText: The COVID-19 virus has not been seen in the breastmilk of any mother with confirmed or suspected cases. Researchers continue to test breastmilk from mothers with confirmed or suspected cases.

questionOriginal: Should mothers breastfeed in communities where COVID-19 is prevalent?
questionText: Should mothers breastfeed in communities where COVID-19 is prevalent?
answerOriginal: Breastfeeding improves survival and provides health and development advantages to babies. Breastfeeding also improves the health of mothers. There is no reason to avoid or stop breastfeeding.
answerText: Breastfeeding improves survival and provides health and development advantages to babies. Breastfeeding also improves the health of mothers. There is no reason to avoid or stop breastfeeding.

questionOriginal: Is it safe to give expressed breastmilk from a mother confirmed/suspected to have COVID-19?
questionText: Is it safe to give expressed breastmilk from a mother confirmed/suspected to have COVID-19?
answerOriginal: The COVID-19 virus has yet not been detected in the breastmilk of any mother confirmed or suspected to have COVID-19.
answerText: The COVID-19 virus has yet not been detected in the breastmilk of any mother confirmed or suspected to have COVID-19.

questionOriginal: How can I protect myself and others?
questionText: How can I protect myself and others?
answerOriginal: The most important action you can take is to frequiently wash your hands. Wash your hands with soap and water for at least 20 seconds, especially after blowing your nose, coughing, sneezing, using the restroom, and before eating or preparing food. If you don't have soap and water, use an alcohol-based hand sanitizer that has at least 60% alcohol. ALWAYS wash your hands with soap and water if your hands are visibly dirty. Please also clean and disinfect frequently touched surfaces (e.g. tables, countertops, light switches, door knobs, cabinet handles). Also avoid close contact with those who are sick. When you are sick, stay at home - except when getting medical care. Cover your coughs and sneezes with tissues, and throw the tissue away. If 'social distancing' measures have been recommended where you are, be certain to follow them.  [[Would you like more information about What are COVID-19 symptoms?]]
answerText: Try to avoid all unnecessary travel at this time. If it is essential to travel, try to avoid contact with sick passengers, mantain as much distance as possible from other passengers, avoid touching your eyes, nose or mouth with unwashed hands, and wash your hands often with soap and water for at least 20 seconds or use hand sanitizer that contains at least 60% alcohol. You should also wear a cloth face covering while at the airport and on the plane.

questionOriginal: Following delivery, should a baby still be immediately placed skin-to-skin and breastfed if the mother is confirmed/suspected to have COVID-19?
questionText: Following delivery, should a baby still be immediately placed skin-to-skin and breastfed if the mother is confirmed/suspected to have COVID-19?
answerOriginal: Immediate skin to skin care improves the baby's health. The many benefits of skin to skin contact and breastfeeding outweighs the potential risks with COVID-19.
answerText: Immediate skin to skin care improves the baby's health. The many benefits of skin to skin contact and breastfeeding outweighs the potential risks with COVID-19.

questionOriginal: If a mother is confirmed/suspected to have COVID-19, should she continue breastfeeding?
questionText: If a mother is confirmed/suspected to have COVID-19, should she continue breastfeeding?
answerOriginal: Mothers should continue breastfeeding. The transmission of the COVID-19 virus through breastmilk and breastfeeding has not been detected. Mothers should still continue hygiene measures, including wearing a medical mask if available, to reduce the chance of viral droplets being spread to her baby.
answerText: Mothers should continue breastfeeding. The transmission of the COVID-19 virus through breastmilk and breastfeeding has not been detected. Mothers should still continue hygiene measures, including wearing a medical mask if available, to reduce the chance of viral droplets being spread to her baby.

questionOriginal: What are the hygiene recommendations for a breastfeeding mother confirmed or suspected to have COVID-19?
questionText: What are the hygiene recommendations for a breastfeeding mother confirmed or suspected to have COVID-19?
answerOriginal: If a mother is confirmed/suspected to have COVID-19 she should: - Wash hands frequently with soap and water or use alcohol based hand rub, especially before touching the baby - Wear a medical mask while feeding. It is important to replace masks as soon as they become damp, dispose of masks immediately, not reuse a mask, and not touch the front of the mask but untie it from behind - Sneeze or cough into a tissue, immediately dispose of it and use alcohol-based hand rub or wash hands again with soap and clean water - Regularly clean and disinfect surfaces
answerText: If a mother is confirmed/suspected to have COVID-19 she should: - Wash hands frequently with soap and water or use alcohol based hand rub, especially before touching the baby - Wear a medical mask while feeding. It is important to replace masks as soon as they become damp, dispose of masks immediately, not reuse a mask, and not touch the front of the mask but untie it from behind - Sneeze or cough into a tissue, immediately dispose of it and use alcohol-based hand rub or wash hands again with soap and clean water - Regularly clean and disinfect surfaces

questionOriginal: If a mother confirmed or suspected to have COVID-19 does not have a medical face mask should she still breastfeed?
questionText: If a mother confirmed or suspected to have COVID-19 does not have a medical face mask should she still breastfeed?
answerOriginal: Mothers should continue breastfeeding. The transmission of the virus through breastmilk and breastfeeding has not been detected. Mothers should still continue wearing a mask if available to reduce the chance of viral droplets being spread to her baby.
answerText: Mothers should continue breastfeeding. The transmission of the virus through breastmilk and breastfeeding has not been detected. Mothers should still continue wearing a mask if available to reduce the chance of viral droplets being spread to her baby.

questionOriginal: Can cold weather and snow kill the new coronavirus?
questionText: Can cold weather and snow kill the new coronavirus?
answerOriginal: There is no reason to believe that cold weather can kill the new coronavirus. The most effective way to protect yourself against the new virus is by cleaning your hands with with soap and water.
answerText: From what experts know so far, it doesn't seem that cold weather kills the COVID-19 virus. The best way to protect yourself against COVID-19 is by cleaning your hands with with soap and water.  [[Would you like more information about How can I protect myself and others?]]

questionOriginal: Does taking a hot bath prevent the new coronavirus disease?
questionText: Does taking a hot bath prevent the new coronavirus disease?
answerOriginal: Taking a hot bath will not prevent you from catching COVID-19. Your normal body temperature remains around 36.5°C to 37°C, regardless of the temperature of your bath or shower. You should avoid taking too hot of a shower as it can burn you. The best way to protect yourself against COVID-19 is by frequently cleaning your hands. By doing this you eliminate viruses that may be on your hands and avoid infection that could occur by then touching your eyes, mouth, and nose.
answerText: Taking a hot bath will not keep you from catching COVID-19. Your body temperature stays around 36.5 to 37 degrees celsius, even if you take a hot bath or shower. Only very hot temperatures can kill the coronavirus. Do not take too hot of a shower, as it could burn you. The best way to protect yourself against COVID-19 is to frequently wash your hands. This helps to remove viruses on your hands that could infect you if you touch your eyes, mouth, and nose.  [[Would you like more information about How can I protect myself and others?]]

questionOriginal: Are hand dryers effective in killing the new coronavirus?
questionText: Are hand dryers effective in killing the new coronavirus?
answerOriginal: Hand dryers alone are not effective in killing the 2019-nCoV. Cleaning your hands is more improtant. To protect yourself against the new coronavirus, you should frequently clean your hands with soap and water or an alcohol-based hand rub if soap and water are not available. Once your hands are cleaned, you should dry them thoroughly by using paper towels or a warm air dryer.
answerText: Hand dryers alone will not kill the COVID-19 virus. But cleaning your hands can! To protect yourself against COVID-19, you should frequently clean your hands with soap and water or an alcohol-based hand sanitizer with at least 60% alcohol if you can't use soap and water. Once your hands are cleaned, dry them well with paper towels or a warm air dryer.  [[Would you like more information about How can I protect myself and others?]]

questionOriginal: Can an ultraviolet disinfection lamp kill the new coronavirus on skin?
questionText: Can an ultraviolet disinfection lamp kill the new coronavirus on skin?
answerOriginal: UV lamps should not be used to clean hands or other areas of skin as UV radiation can cause rashes. Do not use medications or therapies outside of their intended use.
answerText: Don't use ultraviolet (UV) lamps to clean hands or skin because UV rays can cause rashes. Talk to your health care provider before trying a new medication or treatment. Do not use a medication or therapy outside of its intended use.  [[Would you like more information about How can I protect myself and others?]]

questionOriginal: How effective are thermal scanners in detecting people infected with the new coronavirus?
questionText: How effective are thermal scanners in detecting people infected with the new coronavirus?
answerOriginal: Thermal scanners detect fevers  (i.e. have a higher than normal body temperature). Every specific thermal scanner will have different levels of effectiveness in detecting a fever. You should check with the manufacturer to determine the specific level of efficacy for a given scanner.   However, they cannot detect people who are infected but are not yet sick with fever. It takes between 2 and 10 days before people who are infected become sick and develop a fever.
answerText: Thermal scanners detect fevers  (i.e. have a higher than normal body temperature). Some thermal scanners are better than others at detecting a fever. You should check with the manufacturer to learn how well a scanner works.   Thermal scanners cannot detect people who are infected but do not yet have a fever. It takes between 2 and 10 days before people who are infected become sick and get a fever.  [[Would you like more information about What is self-monitoring?]] [[Would you like more information about What are COVID-19 symptoms?]]

questionOriginal: Can regularly rinsing your nose with saline help prevent infection with the new coronavirus?
questionText: Can regularly rinsing your nose with saline help prevent infection with the new coronavirus?
answerOriginal: There is no evidence at this time that rinsing the nose with saline protects people from infection. You should avoid irritating the skin inside your nose as it can make it more susceptible to infections.
answerText: There is no evidence at this time that rinsing the nose with saline prevents infection. You should avoid irritating the skin inside your nose as it can make you more likely to get infected.  [[Would you like more information about How can I protect myself and others?]]

questionOriginal: Are people contagious before they develop symptoms?
questionText: Are people contagious before they develop symptoms?
answerOriginal: The current understanding is that individuals can be contagious before they develop symptoms.
answerText: Most experts think that people can spread the COVID-19 virus before they have symptoms.  [[Would you like more information about What are COVID-19 symptoms?]] [[Would you like more information about How can I protect myself and others?]]

questionOriginal: What is community mitigation?
questionText: What is community mitigation?
answerOriginal: Community mitigation are activities communities take in response to outbreaks. These activities limit the spread of virus. It includes:                                                                              Personal activities like staying home, covering coughs and sneezes and washing hands.  Community strategies like school closures, postponing social gatherings and social distancing.  Environmental activities like cleaning of frequently touched surfaces and objects in homes, schools, workplaces.
answerText: Community mitigation are things that a community does to limit the spread of the virus. It includes:                                                                              1. Personal activities like staying home, covering coughs and sneezes and washing hands.  2. Community strategies like school closures, postponing social gatherings and social distancing.  3. Environmental activities like cleaning frequently touched surfaces and objects in homes, schools, and workplaces.  [[Would you like more information about What is social distancing?]] [[Would you like more information about How can I protect myself and others?]]

questionOriginal: Is it dangerous to be outdoors?
questionText: Is it dangerous to be outdoors?
answerOriginal: You must check your local government policies to see if its acceptable for individuals to go outside for non-essential needss. If you do go outside, it is important to continue social distancing behaviors and aavoid close contact with other individuals by maintaing a 6-foot distance with others. If you are age 60 or over or have an underlying health condition, be extra careful about being around others.
answerText: Check your local government policies to see if it is ok for people to go outside for non-essential needs. If you go outside, continue to following social distancing and avoid close contact with others by staying at least 6 feet (2 meters) away from other people. If you are age 60 or over or have an underlying health condition, be extra careful about being around others.  [[Would you like more information about What is social distancing?]] [[Would you like more information about Is there COVID-19 in my area?]] [[Would you like more information about Who is at a higher risk of severe illness?]]

questionOriginal: What is a coronavirus?
questionText: What is a coronavirus?
answerOriginal: Coronaviruses are a large family of viruses. There are different types of coronaviruses.  Some types of coronavirus are more common in people and some versions are more common in animals. Rarely, a type of the virus that was common in animals can spread to people. "Coronavirus Disease 2019” (which is shortened to "COVID-19") is an example of a type of coronavirus that has recently spread to humans.     [[Would you like more information about What is COVID-19?]] [[Would you like more information about What are COVID-19 symptoms?]] [[Would you like more information about What is novel (new) coronavirus?]]

questionOriginal: What is novel (new) coronavirus?
questionText: What is novel (new) coronavirus?
answerOriginal: A "novel" virus means that scientists haven't seen this type of the virus before.  "Coronavirus Disease 2019” which is shortened to "COVID-19" is type of a virus that has never been seen before in humans. This means that the body needs to learn how to fight off this new type of virus.  [[Would you like more information about What is COVID-19?]] [[Would you like more information about What is a coronavirus?]]

questionOriginal: What is COVID-19?
questionText: What is COVID-19?
answerOriginal: COVID-19 is a disease caused by a new type of virus. Sometimes people also call it "coronavirus," which is is the type of virus that causes COVID-19. COVID-19 causes some symptoms that are like getting a cold or flu. But some people get worse symptoms and need more care. COVID-19 is caused by a new type of virus that our body has not seen before. Since our body has not seen it before, our immune system has to learn how to fight off this new virus.     [[Would you like more information about What are COVID-19 symptoms?]]

questionOriginal: What is SARS-CoV-2?
questionText: What is SARS-CoV-2?
answerOriginal: SARS-COV-2 is the name for the virus that causes the disease known as "COVID-19." Let's break it down.  "SARS" stands for "Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome", meaning that it can cause serious problems with breathing and the lungs.    "COV" stands for "Coronavirus." This is the type of virus that causes COVID-19.   The "2" is a way to say that this virus is different than the SARS virus that caused an outbreak in 2002-2003. questionOriginal: What is MERS-CoV?
questionText: What is MERS-CoV?
answerOriginal: MERS-CoV is one type of coronavirus. It is different type from the type of coronavirus that causes COVID-19. MERS-CoV stands for "Middle East Respiratory Syndrome- associated Coronavirus."  The first cases of MERS-CoV were seen in 2012 in Saudi Arabia. MERS-CoV symptoms are fever, cough, and shortness of breath. People with this disease usually do not get sick from one another unless they are in very close contact.  [[Would you like more information about What is SARS-CoV-2?]] [[Would you like more information about What is a coronavirus?]]

questionOriginal: When is COVID-19 going to stop?
questionText: When is COVID-19 going to stop?
answerOriginal: Unfortunately, we do not know when COVID-19 will stop. Right now, to protect yourself and others from getting sick, you should:  -Practice social distancing -Stay at home as much as possible,  -Wash your hands frequently with soap and water for at least 20 seconds -Follow the guidelines of your local and state health department for what actvities are allowed -If you do have to go out, maintain a 6-foot physical distance between yourself and others. questionOriginal: What can I do to prevent getting COVID-19?
questionText: What can I do to prevent getting COVID-19?
answerOriginal: The most important thing is to wash your hands. Use soap and water for at least 20 seconds, especially after blowing your nose, coughing, sneezing, using the restroom, or before or after eating or making food. ALWAYS wash your hands with soap and water if your hands look dirty. If you cannot wash your hands, use hand sanitizer that has at least 60 percent alcohol.     Here are some other things you can do to reduce your risk of getting COVID-19:    - Clean and disinfect surfaces that you touch a lot, like tables, counters, light switches, door knobs, and cabinet handles.   - Cover your coughs and sneezes with tissues and throw the tissue away.   - Stay at home if you are sick.   - Don't get too close to people who are sick.   - If "social distancing" measures are in effect where you are, be sure to follow them.     [[Would you like more information about What are COVID-19 symptoms?]]   [[Would you like more information about What is social distancing?]]

questionOriginal: What is a virus?
questionText: What is a virus?
answerOriginal: A virus is a very small particle that infect other cells. Viruses that infect people can make them sick.  Viruses are tiny, smaller than bacteria or fungi. They are small pieces of genetic material (DNA or RNA) surrounded by a protein shell. Viruses cannot survive long on their own. They need to use a living cell to live and reproduce. Once a virus enters a cell, it takes over that cell and uses it to make more viruses that go on to infect other cells.  [[Would you like more information about What is a coronavirus?]]

questionOriginal: Why is COVID-19 dangerous?
questionText: Why is COVID-19 dangerous?
answerOriginal: There are a few reasons why people are very concerned about COVID-19. First, it is a new virus that humans have never had before. Our bodies haven't learned how to fight it off yet. Second, the virus is very infectious and has spread quickly around the world. Third, about 1 out of every 5 people who gets COVID-19 needs medical care in a hospital. Some hospitals will have trouble caring for this many sick people at the same time. Fourth, doctors and scientists still don't know very much about COVID-19 or how to treat it yet. Everyone is learning more every day.  [[Would you like more information about Who is at a higher risk for serious illness?]]

questionOriginal: What is the difference between a pandemic and epidemic?
questionText: What is the difference between a pandemic and epidemic?
answerOriginal: A pandemic is a global outbreak of disease that affects many people in different places.  An epidemic is an outbreak in a certain area or among a specific group of people over a particular period of time.   [[Would you like more information about Why did the World Health Organization (WHO) declare this a pandemic?]]

An epidemic is an outbreak in a certain area or among a specific group of people over a particular period of time.   [[Would you like more information about Why did the World Health Organization (WHO) declare this a pandemic?]]

questionOriginal: Why did the World Health Organization (WHO) declare this a pandemic?
questionText: Why did the World Health Organization (WHO) declare this a pandemic?
answerOriginal: The World Health Organization, or WHO, declared the COVID-19 outbreak to be a pandemic because it was likely that the virus was going to spread to all countries in the world. Declaring COVID-19 to be a pandemic helps to alert countries to prepare for the virus.   [[Would you like more information about What is the difference between a pandemic and epidemic?]]

questionOriginal: Why are the death rates so different across countries?
questionText: Why are the death rates so different across countries?
answerOriginal: The death rates are different between countries for a few reasons. The main reason is because some countries have tested more people than others.   Death rates can seem higher in countries where fewer people are tested. That's because death rates compare the number of people who have died from a disease to the number of people who have the disease, whether they die or not. When countries only test patients who are sick enough to go to the hospital and are not testing those who are less sick, this makes death rates seem higher than they are.

questionOriginal: Has COVID-19 mutated?
questionText: Has COVID-19 mutated?
answerOriginal: Like most viruses, the virus that causes COVID-19 is also mutating, which means changing its RNA structure. It is normal for viruses to mutate.  Right now, the mutations are probably not changing how the virus spreads or makes people sick.

questionOriginal: Can you smoke weed/cannabis during COVID-19?

This could also happen for people who smoke weed or cannabis.  As for the effect of CBD and cannabis, right now we don’t have any studies showing if it affects coronovirus.

questionOriginal: What is the impact of COVID-19?
questionText: What is the impact of COVID-19?
answerOriginal: COVID-19 is likely impact our lives in many ways. On the community level, this oubreak might lead to a decrease in polarization, more trust in science, and less individualism. On a lifestyle-level, this outbreak has moved even more of our activities online and might be a new boon to virtual reality. In terms of our health, there is likely to be a rise on telemedicine and an opening stronger family care. It is quite obvious that the global economy has taken a big toll due to COVID-19. Some experts say that there will be more restraints on mass consumption, stronger domestic supply chains, and a widening of the inequality gap, following the pandemic.

questionOriginal: Will COVID-19 go away like the 1918 influenza and SARS did?
questionText: Will COVID-19 go away like the 1918 influenza and SARS did?
answerOriginal: There is a lot left to be learned about this virus and how, when, and whether it will go away like previous outbreaks. However, in an absence of vaccines and effective treatments, the best thing we can do to practice social distancing, take care of ourselves, and stay hopeful.

questionOriginal: How many asymptomatic people are there globally?
questionText: How many asymptomatic people are there globally?
answerOriginal: This is quite a difficult question. Although there is not an authoritative of asymptomatic cases globally, it is estimated that 25 percent of people infected with the new coronavirus don't present any symptoms or fall ill but can still transmit the illness to others.
answerText: It is hard to know how many asymptomatic people there are in the world. As of now, it seems that many people who are infected may not show symptoms.

questionOriginal: What is a biological medical product or a biologic?
questionText: What is a biological medical product or a biologic?
answerOriginal: A biological medical product (sometimes called "biologic") is a medicine made from natural sources or using biotechnology or other new technology. Some types of biologics are vaccines, blood, and other things made from human cells. They can come from humans, animals, or microorganisms. They can be made of sugars, proteins, and/or nucleic acids, or they can be living things.  [[Would you like more information about What vaccines or treatments are available for COVID-19?]]

questionText: What is a state of emergency? Does it indicate the severity of a situation?

questionOriginal: What are respiratory droplets?
questionText: What are respiratory droplets?
answerOriginal: Respiratory droplets are little drops that come from your nose or mouth when you sneeze, cough, talk, or breathe. They can stay in the air, or they can be passed from one person to another by touching commonly used surfaces such as door knobs, elevator buttons and faucets.  [[Would you like more information about What can I do to prevent getting COVID-19?]]

questionOriginal: How does COVID-19 spread?
questionText: How does COVID-19 spread?
answerOriginal: COVID-19 can spread in a few different ways. It can spread from person to person if you inhale an infected person's respiratory droplets when they sneezes, coughs, or talk. It can also spead if you touch something that an infected person has touched, like a door knob, elevator button, or bathroom faucet.  That's why it's important to wash your hands, avoid touching your face, and practice social distancing to avoid getting sick. That's why it's also important to self-isolate and wear a mask around other household members if you are sick to avoid infecting other people.  [[Would you like more information about What is social distancing?]] [[Would you like more information about What is self-isolation?]] [[Would you like more information about Does hand-washing kill the virus?]]

questionOriginal: Does COVID-19 transfer through the air?
questionText: Does COVID-19 transfer through the air?
answerOriginal: Yes. We are still learning about how easily COVID-19 can transfer through the air. Small droplets can probably stay in the air for a short time after someone coughs or sneezes and those could infect someone. Also, some medical procedures can cause very small droplets that stay in the air for a longer time.  Scientists think that the main way you could get infected is if you were in close contact with an infected person and had your mouth, nose, or eyes exposed to infected respiratory droplets.  [[Would you like more information about How does COVID-19 spread?]] [[Would you like more information about What are respiratory droplets?]]

questionOriginal: How long does COVID-19 live on surfaces?
questionText: How long does COVID-19 live on surfaces?
answerOriginal: In an experiment, scientists found that the virus could live:  -On plastic for up to 72 hours (3 days) -On stainless steel for up to 48 hours (2 days) -On cardboard for up to 24 hours (1 day) -On copper for up to 4 hours -In the air for up to 3 hours  Scientists still need to do more research to find out if these results also apply to the real world.  It is important to clean and disinfect surfaces that people touch a lot.You should also wash your hands frequently with soap and water or use a hand sanitizer with at leat 60% alcohol if soap and water are not available.  [[Would you like more information about What can I do to prevent getting COVID-19?]]

questionText: What is "flattening the curve"?

questionText: Why do I have to stay at home?
answerOriginal: Staying at home and using "social distancing" helps stop the virus from spreading quickly. This helps to reduce the burden on healthcare systems, as there are not enough hospital workers and beds if too many people get sick at once.  Social distancing means staying farther away from other people and avoiding groups of people. Since COVID-19 mostly spreads from person-to-person interactions, staying at least 6 feet away from other people can help stop the spread. It is important to use social distancing because people can spread COVID-19 even if they feel fine. It is especially important to use social distancing to protect people who are more likely to get very sick from the disease.  [[Would you like more information about What is social distancing?]] [[Would you like more information about What is self-isolation?]]

questionOriginal: What is self-isolation?
questionText: What is self-isolation?
answerOriginal: Self-isolation means that people who are sick stay away from those who are not sick. This helps to keep the disease from spreading. If someone has asked you to self-isolate, you should:  -Stay at home except to get medical care -Stay away from other people in your home as much as you can -Wear a face mask if you have to be around other people (for example, in a doctor's office) -Cover your coughs and sneezes -Wash your hands a lot -Keep track of your symptoms  Go here to read more about how you should self-isolate, visit this page: https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/if-you-are-sick/steps-when-sick.html   [[Would you like more information about What is social-distancing?]] [[Would you like more information about What are COVID-19 symptoms?]]

questionOriginal: What is self-monitoring?
questionText: What is self-monitoring?
answerOriginal: Self-monitoring means that people should monitor themselves for fever by taking their temperatures twice a day and paying attention if they begin coughing or have trouble breathing. If they start to get symptoms during this self-monitoring period, they should self-isolate, limit their contact with others, and seek medical advice by telephone if possible.  [[Would you like more information about What is self-isolation?]]

questionOriginal: What's the difference between self-isolating and self-monitoring?
questionText: What's the difference between self-isolating and self-monitoring?
answerOriginal: The difference between self-monitoring and self-isolation is based on whether you have been diagnosed with COVID-19 or not. If you may have been exposed to COVID-19 but don't have symptoms, you should self-monitor. If you have been diagnosed with COVID-19, you should self-isolate.  You need to self-monitor if you have no symptoms but may have been exposed to COVID-19 in the last 14 days or are in close contact with older adults, people who are medically vulnerable or have been asked to do so by your Public Health Authority. Self-monitoring means you should:  -Monitor yourself for 14 days for symptoms like fever, cough, and trouble breathing -Stay at home -Avoid crowded places -Stay at least 6 feet away from others as much as you can -Wash your hands frequently  You need to self-isolate if you have been confirmed to have COVID-19. Isolation means keeping infected people away from those who are not infected. If you have been asked to self-isolate, you should:  -Stay home except to get medical care -Stay away from other people in your home as much as you can -Wear a face mask if you need to be around other people (for example, in a doctor's office) -Cover your coughs and sneezes -Wash your hands frequently -Keep checking your symptoms until your doctor says you don't need to be in isolation any more  [[Would you like more information about What are COVID-19 symptoms?]] [[Would you like more information about What should I do if I think I have COVID-19?]]

questionOriginal: What is social distancing?
questionText: What is social distancing?
answerOriginal: Social distancing means staying home and limiting contact with other people as much as you can. Social distancing is important because it reduces the spread of illness. You might need to change your habits to do social distancing well. For example:  -Avoid groups of people as much as you can -Don't shake hands or touch people to greet them -Don't go to crowded places such as concerts, arenas, conferences, or festivals -Stay away from people at high risk for severe symptoms, such as older people and those in poor health -Stay at least 2 arms' length (about 6 feet) away from others.  For example, if you need to buy groceries, limit this to once a week. If you go on walks, stay at least 6 feet away from others.

questionOriginal: Should I wear a face mask?
questionText: Should I wear a face mask?
answerOriginal: Face masks, including fabric ones, are likely only helpful in preventing people who have COVID-19 from spreading it to others. If you wear a cloth mask, you should still use the same social distancing measures as you would if you were not wearing a mask. This means you should stay at least 6 feet (2 meters) away from other people, wash your hands frequently, and avoid touching your face or eyes.  When wearing a mask, make sure it covers your nose and mouth. Wash the mask after you use it every time. When handling the mask, act as though the front of the mask is contaminated. Don't touch the front of the mask when you take it off or put it on.  It is not recommended that the general public wear surgical or N95 masks at this time. That is because there are not enough of these masks for health care workers. Health care workers need these masks to stay safe and to take care of sick patients. If you have extra surgical or N95 masks, please donate them to your local healthcare facility.  [[Would you like more information about What is social distancing?]] [[Would you like more information about What is self-isolation?]] [[Would you like more information about How do you put on, use, take off, and dispose of a face mask?]]
