questionOriginal: What are N95 respirators/masks?
questionText: What are N95 respirators/masks?
answerOriginal: This is a type of personal protective equipment that forms a tight seal around the nose and mouth to avoid airborne particles and fluid from entering. These masks are not "one size fits all" so people who depend on them for the job must get fit-tested before using them.   It is not recommended that the general public wear  N95 masks at this time. That is because there are not enough of these masks for health care workers. Health care workers need these masks to stay safe and to take care of sick patients. If you have extra N95 masks, please donate them to your local healthcare facility.  [[Would you like more information about Should I wear a face mask?]] [[Would you like more information about What is personal protective equipment (PPE)?]]

questionOriginal: What is personal protective equipment (PPE)?
questionText: What is personal protective equipment (PPE)?
answerOriginal: Personal protective equipment (PPE) are types of equipment worn to reduce the chance of someone getting a workplace injury or illness. Examples include gloves, safety glasses, shoes, earplugs or muffs, hard hats, respirators, coveralls, etc.   PPE is very important during this pandemic because there are not enough face masks for frontline health workers.  [[Would you like more information about What are N95 respirators/masks?]] [[Would you like more information about Should I wear a face mask?]]

questionOriginal: Is COVID-19 contagious?
questionText: Is COVID-19 contagious?
answerOriginal: COVID-19 is contagious and it is actively spreading from person to person. The CDC recommends that those who have COVID-19 are isolated either at a hospital or at home, depending on how sick they are, until they are no longer at risk of infecting others.  [[Would you like more information about How does COVID-19 spread?]] [[Would you like more information about What is community spread?]]

questionOriginal: How long are you contagious for if you have COVID-19?
questionText: How long are you contagious for if you have COVID-19?
answerOriginal: We aren't sure exactly how long people are contagious from COVID-19. If you have been sick with COVID-19 and have been in isolation, you should talk to your healthcare provider to decide when you can be released from isolation. Your doctor will look for signs that:  -You are fever-free without taking fever-reducing medication -You no longer show symptoms -Sometimes, your doctor might recommend testing respiratory samples to decide if you can be released from isolation  Once you have been released from isolation, then you are no longer considered to be likely to infect other people.  [[Would you like more information about What are COVID-19 symptoms?]]

questionOriginal: How long after being asymptomatic are you no longer contagious?
questionText: How long after being asymptomatic are you no longer contagious?
answerOriginal: If you think that you've been exposed to COVID-19, and are asymptomatic, you should quarantine for at least 14 days, or 2 weeks, from the time that you think you might have been exposed. That's because most people who get COVID-19 show symptoms within 14 days. questionOriginal: Is the virus infectious during incubation period?
questionText: Is the virus infectious during incubation period?
answerOriginal: Yes, the virus can spread from person to person during incubation period. The “incubation period” means the time between catching the virus and beginning to have symptoms of the disease. If you may have been exposed to the virus and do not have any symptoms, please self-quarantine. If you are having COVID-19 symptoms, please self-isolate.   [[Would you like more information about what is self-isolation?]] [[Would you like more information about what is self-quarantine?]] [[Would you like more information about what are COVID-19 symptoms?]]

questionOriginal: What is the difference between isolation and quarantine?
questionText: What is the difference between isolation and quarantine?
answerOriginal: You need to self-isolate if you have been confirmed to have COVID-19. Isolation is a health care term that means keeping infected people away from those who are not infected. If you have been asked to self-isolate, you should:  -Stay at home except to get medical care -Stay away from other people in your home as much as you can -Wear a face mask if you need to be around other people (for example, in a doctor's office) -Cover your coughs and sneezes -Wash your hands frequently -Continue to monitor your symptoms until your doctor says you don't need to be in isolation any more  Quarantine means staying away from other people because you might have been exposed to the virus. For COVID-19, people should quarantine for at least 14 days, or 2 weeks from the time they might have had contact with someone with COVID-19. That's because most people who get COVID-19 would have symptoms within 14 days. Scientists think that people are not likely to spread COVID-19 to others if they do not get sick after 14 days.  [[Would you like more information about What is the difference between self-monitoring and self-isolation?]] [[Would you like more information about What are COVID-19 symptoms?]]

questionOriginal: What does it mean to be isolated if you live with other people?
questionText: What does it mean to be isolated if you live with other people?
answerOriginal: If the infected person lives with others, it is important to keep them apart from others as much as possible. This means they should stay in another room as much as they can and use a separate bedroom and bathroom if possible.  If you are living with someone who is infected, you should:  -Avoid sharing household items like dishes, cups, towels, and bedding -Wash your hands regularly or use hand sanitizer that is at least 60% alcohol -Clean and disinfect surfaces that people touch a lot -Wash laundry frequently and thoroughly -If you have pets, the infected person should not care for them -Don't have visitors in your home

questionOriginal: Can COVID-19 be spread through food (including refrigerated or frozen food)?
questionText: Can COVID-19 be spread through food (including refrigerated or frozen food)?
answerOriginal: Current thinking is that COVID-19 mostly spreads from person to person through respiratory droplets. Scientists are still studying how long coronavirus lives on surfaces. In general, you should practice good hygiene and food safety practices. This means cleaning surfaces that are used a lot, cleaning your fruits and vegetables, and cooking meats well. Wash your hands with soap and water before handling food. questionOriginal: Will warm weather stop the COVID-19 outbreak?
questionText: Will warm weather stop the COVID-19 outbreak?
answerOriginal: We do not know if warm weather will slow the COVID-19 spread. Some viruses, like the common cold or flu, spread better during the cold weather months than in the warm weather months. We are still learning about how weather and temperature affect spread of COVID-19.

questionOriginal: Will high temperatures or heat kill COVID-19?
questionText: Will high temperatures or heat kill COVID-19?
answerOriginal: Hot water can kill germs, but it has to be very hot - too hot for humans to bear without injuring themselves. Being out in the sun or hot weather, taking long baths, or using hand dryers will not prevent you from getting COVID-19. Also, the virus is still spreading in countries with hot weather.  [[Would you like more information about How does COVID-19 spread?]]

questionOriginal: Will herd immunity be the only means of controlling COVID-19?
questionText: Will herd immunity be the only means of controlling COVID-19?
answerOriginal: Herd immunity is not the only way to control COVID-19.   Herd immunity is when enough of the population is immune to an infectious disease that the disease will not spread easily from person to person. This could happen either because most people are vaccinated for the disease or because they were sick before and are now immune. For COVID-19, that would mean that enough people would have to recover from the disease and become immune to reduce the person-to-person spread since there is not a vaccine yet.  The other way of controlling the spread of COVID-19 is to practice social distancing and frequent hand-washing. This helps to prevent too many people from getting sick with COVID-19 at once, which could lead to more sick people than hospitals can handle.   [[Would you like more information about What is social distancing?]] [[Would you like more information about How does COVID-19 spread?]] [[Would you like more information about Can you be re-infected with COVID-19?]]

questionOriginal: Does hand-washing kill the virus?
questionText: Does hand-washing kill the virus?
answerOriginal: Hand-washing is one of the best ways to keep yourself and your family from getting sick. Washing your hands well can remove all tarces of the virus on your hands. To wash your hands well,  use soap and water for at least 20 seconds.   Make sure to wash your hands:  - After blowing your nose, coughing, or sneezing - After using the restroom - Before or after eating or making food - After being in a public place - After touching things that many other people have touched like door handles or tables  If you cannot wash your hands, use hand sanitizer that has at least 60 percent alcohol. However, hand sanitizers do not get rid of all types of germs, so it is best to wash your hands as soon as you can.  [[Would you like more information about How does COVID-19 spread?]]

questionOriginal: Does washing clothes in the washing machine prevent transmission?
questionText: Does washing clothes in the washing machine prevent transmission?
answerOriginal: The virus that causes COVID-19 is very susceptible to soaps. So when you wash clothes, use detergent. The CDC says it is fine to wash an infected person’s clothes with those of someone who is not ill. The CDC advises using your regular laundry detergent and then drying the clothes thoroughly at the warmest temperature recommended on the clothing label.

The CDC advises using your regular laundry detergent and then drying the clothes thoroughly at the warmest temperature recommended on the clothing label.

questionOriginal: How does COVID-19 kill people?
questionText: How does COVID-19 kill people?
answerOriginal: Most people don't die from COVID-19. But COVID-19 can kill people by causing lung infection (pneumonia) and swelling (inflammation). When the immune system tries to fight off the pneumonia, this can lead to too much inflammation and damage to the lungs. When this happens, not enough oxygen goes to important organs like the liver, kidney, and brain. If the lung damage is too bad and not enough oxygen gets to the rest of the body, this can cause organ failure and death.  [[Would you like more information about Who is at higher risk of severe illness?]]

questionOriginal: Can disinfectant sprays or wipes be used on my skin to prevent the spread of COVID-19?
questionText: Can disinfectant sprays or wipes be used on my skin to prevent the spread of COVID-19?
answerOriginal: Do not use disinfectant sprays or wipes on your skin because they may bother your skin or eyes. Always follow the instructions and warning labels on cleaning products. Disinfectant sprays or wipes are intended for use on hard, non-porous surfaces, not on humans or animals. Never drink or eat disinfectant sprays or wipes. questionOriginal: Can the new coronavirus be transmitted through mosquito bites?
questionText: Can the new coronavirus be transmitted through mosquito bites?
answerOriginal: To date there has been no information nor evidence that the virus occurs because of mosquitoes. The new virus spreads mostly through droplets when an infected person coughs or sneezes, or through saliva or discharge from the nose. To protect yourself, clean your hands as much as you can with with soap and water or an alcohol based hand rub. Also, avoid close contact with anyone who is coughing and sneezing.

questionOriginal: Can spraying alcohol or chlorine all over your body kill the new coronavirus?
questionText: Can spraying alcohol or chlorine all over your body kill the new coronavirus?
answerOriginal: Spraying alcohol or chlorine all over your body will not kill viruses that have already entered your body. Additionally, several of these sprays can be toxic to your skin and can cause rashes or chemical burns. You should carefully read the use and warning label on any product before using it on your body. Do not use household cleaners on your skin and do not eat or drink household cleaners.

questionOriginal: What is the definition of close contact?
questionText: What is the definition of close contact?
answerOriginal: Close contact is defined as: a. Being within 6 feet (2 meters) of someone with COVID-19. Close contact can occur while caring for, living with, visiting, or sharing a health care waiting area or room with someone with COVID-19.  – or – b. Having direct contact with infectious body fluids of a COVID-19 case (e.g., being coughed on).

questionOriginal: Who should get tested for COVID-19?
questionText: Who should get tested for COVID-19?
answerOriginal: Not everyone needs to be tested for COVID-19. Doctors and state health departments work to decide who should be tested based on their symptoms. Some of the factors that help decide if someone needs testing include their symptoms, how sick they are, if they have other health problems, and if they have contact with other vulnerable groups. questionOriginal: How can I get tested for COVID-19?
questionText: How can I get tested for COVID-19?
answerOriginal: Not everyone needs to be tested for COVID-19. Getting tested usually will NOT help you get better treatment because currently there are no approved treatments for COVID-19. most people will not get very sick and can get better at home. Since there are not enough tests for everyone, it is important to make sure that people like health care workers and other high-risk groups can get tested first.  Please call your health care provider or the health department in your town or state to find out if you need to be tested. questionOriginal: What should I do if I think I have COVID-19?
questionText: What should I do if I think I have COVID-19?
answerOriginal: If you have one of these symptoms, you should call 911 or emergency medical services to seek care right away:  -Trouble breathing -Pain or pressure in the chest that won't go away -Feeling confused -Lips or face that look blue  If this is not an emergency, this symptom checker by the Centers for Disease Control (CDC) can help you find out if you could have COVID-19. questionOriginal: Can a person test negative and later test positive for COVID-19?
questionText: Can a person test negative and later test positive for COVID-19?
answerOriginal: In general, a negative or normal result means that the virus that causes COVID-19 was not found in the sample. But sometimes if a person has COVID-19 in the early stages, they could test negative at first, but test positive later on, when there is more virus present. You healthcare provider can help decide if you should be tested again.  [[Would you like more information about Who should get tested for COVID-19?]]

questionOriginal: What vaccines or treatments are available for COVID-19?
questionText: What vaccines or treatments are available for COVID-19?
answerOriginal: There is currently no vaccine or treatment  for COVID-19, and it might take some time to make one. Right now, scientists are still studying vaccines and some drug treatments to see if they are safe and if they work.  Luckily, most people who get COVID-19 will recover on their own or with treatment with over-the-counter cold or flu medications. Do NOT try to prevent or treat your COVID-19 symptoms using drugs like antibiotics. Talk to your doctor before starting a new medication.  [[Would you like more information about What can I do to prevent getting COVID-19?]]

questionOriginal: Should I take chloroquine?
questionText: Should I take chloroquine?
answerOriginal: Chloroquine Phosphate is a medicine that people usually use to prevent or treat malaria. As of April 2020, it has not been approved to treat COVID-19.   It has been used in experiments to treat a few people with COVID-19 but scientists don't know for sure if it works. Scientists are still testing it.   Please talk to your doctor before taking any medication.   [[Would you like more information about what vaccines or treatments are available for COVID-19?]]

questionText: Should I take hydroxychloroquinine?
answerOriginal: You should not take hydroxychloroquine unless a doctor prescribed it to you for a specific health issue. It can also have dangerous side effects if you take the wrong dose.

questionOriginal: Why are ventilators needed?
questionText: Why are ventilators needed?
answerOriginal: A ventilator is a machine that helps you breathe if your body can not do it on its own. COVID-19 can make it hard to breathe. In severe cases, a person with COVID-19 may need help breathing using a ventilator.  [[Would you like more information about Who is at higher risk of severe illness?]]

questionOriginal: How often should I take my temperature?
questionText: How often should I take my temperature?
answerOriginal: If you think you could have been exposed or infected with COVID-19, take your temperature two times a day (morning and night) every day for 14 days. You should also take your temperature if you start to feel sick or if you think you might have a fever.  [[Would you like more information about What is self-monitoring?]]

questionOriginal: Will a pneumococcal vaccine help protect me against coronavirus
questionText: Will a pneumococcal vaccine help protect me against coronavirus
answerOriginal: Vaccines against pneumonia, such as the pneumococcal vaccine, do not protect against COVID-19.
answerText: Vaccines against pneumonia, such as the pneumococcal vaccine, do not protect against COVID-19.

questionOriginal: Do the test results work if you don't have symptoms?
questionText: Do the test results work if you don't have symptoms?
answerOriginal: The COVID-19 test usually does not help most people without symptoms, although your health care provider might decide to test you if you were exposed to an infected person. Sometimes you can test positive if you are infected but don't have symptoms yet. But no test is perfect. You could also get a "false negative" result. This means that you could still have the disease even if the test result is negative (normal).   You should continue to stay at home if possible and follow social distancing guidelines, even if you do not have symptoms.  [[What is social distancing?]] [[What are COVID-19 symptoms?]] [[What is self-monitoring?]]

questionOriginal: Should I use NSAIDs?
questionText: Should I use NSAIDs?
answerOriginal: At this time, there is not scientific evidence to show if NSAIDs (non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs), like ibuprofen, make COVID-19 symptoms worse. But scientists are still studying this. If you are worried about using NSAIDs, speak to your health care provider to learn more.

questionOriginal: How can I get tested if I am asymptomatic?
questionText: How can I get tested if I am asymptomatic?
answerOriginal: If you do not have symptoms such as fever, cough or shortness of breath, you probably do not need to be tested for COVID-19 at this time. Getting tested usually will NOT help you get better treatment. You should continue to stay at home as much as you can and follow social distancing guidelines, even if you do not feel sick.  Please contact your provider if you begin to havesymptoms of COVID-19 or if you have any changes in your health.  [[Would you like more information about What are COVID-19 symptoms?]] [[Would you like more information about What is social distancing?]]

questionOriginal: How long is the treatment?
questionText: How long is the treatment?
answerOriginal: At this time, there is no  treatment for COVID-19. Most people who get COVID-19 will recover on their own or with treatment with over-the-counter cold or flu medications. People who have more severe illness might need to go to the hospital for care. The length of time to recovery varies from one person to another. Most people take about two weeks to recover from COVID-19. People with severe symptoms or other conditions might take between 3 and 6 weeks to recover.

questionOriginal: How long does it take to get the test results back?
questionText: How long does it take to get the test results back?
answerOriginal: How long it takes to get results backs depends on which test was used and which laboratory is doing the testing. It can take up to one week to get test results back. You should ask the the provider that did the test how long they think it will take for the test results to come.  While waiting for your results, please stay at home and monitor your symptoms. If your symptoms get worse, please contact your provider.  [[Would you like more information about What is self-monitoring?]] [[Would you like more information about What are COVID-19 symptoms?]]

questionOriginal: How to treat coronavirus naturally?
questionText: How to treat coronavirus naturally?
answerOriginal: If you are at home with mild symptoms, you may be able to relieve symptoms by getting extra rest and sleep, drinking enough liquids to stay hydrated, staying warm, and using a humidifier or taking a hot shower to help a sore throat and cough. If you are thinking about taking any supplement or natural medicine, please talk to your healthcare provider first to make sure there are no negative side effects. Right now, there is no evidence that any supplements or natural medicines can treat COVID-19.

questionOriginal: I recently recovered from COVID-19, can I donate convalescent plasma?
questionText: I recently recovered from COVID-19, can I donate convalescent plasma?
answerOriginal: You may donate convalescent plasma if you have recovered and are eligible to donate blood. You must be symptom free for 14 days before donating.

questionOriginal: If I spray chlorine or alcohol on my skin, will it kill the viruses in my body?
questionText: If I spray chlorine or alcohol on my skin, will it kill the viruses in my body?
answerOriginal: Spraying chlorine, alcohol, or other substances on your body will not kill viruses inside your body.
answerText: Spraying chlorine, alcohol, or other substances on your body will not kill viruses inside your body.

questionOriginal: If I am able to hold my breath for 10 seconds, does that mean I don't have COVID-19?
questionText: If I am able to hold my breath for 10 seconds, does that mean I don't have COVID-19?
answerOriginal: While shortness of breath is a symptom of COVID-19, holding your breath for 10 or more seconds is not a test for COVID-19. This should not be used in place of a COVID-19 test to determine whether or not you have COVID-19.
answerText: While shortness of breath is a symptom of COVID-19, holding your breath for 10 or more seconds is not a test for COVID-19. This should not be used in place of a COVID-19 test to determine whether or not you have COVID-19.

questionOriginal: If I'm high risk, what should I do?
questionText: If I'm high risk, what should I do?
answerOriginal: If you are high risk, stock up on supplies like nonperishable foods and medicines; if you must interact with others, take everyday precautions to keep space and distance between yourself and others; avoid people who are sick; avoid crowds, and wash your hands often with soap and water and avoid touching your face. Please limit travel and stay at home as much as possible. If there is an outbreak in your community, stay at home as much as possible and watch for symptoms and emergency signs. If you do get sick, call your doctor.   To learn more about how to prepare, click here: https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/specific-groups/high-risk-complications.html
answerText: If you are high risk and there is an outbreak near you, you should: 1. Stay home as much as you can  2. Stock up on supplies like nonperishable foods and medicines  3. Limit travel as much as you can  4. Watch for symptoms and emergency signs    If you must interact with others, you should: 1. Keep at least 6 feet (2 meters) away from other people  2. Stay away from crowds  3. Stay away from people who are sick  4. Wash your hands often with soap and water  5. Don't touch your face    If you get sick, please call your doctor.   To learn more about how to prepare, click here: https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/specific-groups/high-risk-complications.html  [[Would you like more information about Who is at higher risk of severe illness?]] [[Would you like more information about What are COVID-19 symptoms?]] [[Would you like more information about Is there COVID-19 in my area?]]

questionOriginal: How do you put on, use, take off, and dispose of a face mask?
questionText: How do you put on, use, take off, and dispose of a face mask?
answerOriginal: First, please remember that face masks should only be used by health workers, caretakers, and individuals who are exhibiting symptoms (e.g. cough, fever).   1. Before touching the mask, washing your hands with soap and water or an alcohol-based hand sanitizer. 2. Take the mask and inspect it for tears and holes. 3. Orient which side is the top side (which is where the metal strip is) 4. Ensure that the proper side of the mask is facing outwards (the colored side) 5. Place the mask to your face. Pinch the metal strip or the stiff edge of the mask so it molds to the shape of your nose. 6. Pull down the bottom of the mask so it is covering your mouth and chin 7. After use, take the mask off - remove the elastic loops from behind your ears, while keeping the mask away from your face and clothes. This is to avoid touching potentially contaminated surfaces of the mask 8. Discard the mask in a closed trash can immediately after use 9. Wash your hands with soap and water or an alcohol-based hand sanitizer after touching / discarding the mask.
answerText: First, please remember that surgical masks should only be used by health workers, caretakers, and people who have COVID-19 symptoms like a cough or a fever.  To put on a surgical mask, you should: 1. Wash your hands with soap and water or use an alcohol-based hand sanitizer BEFORE touching the mask 2. Look at the mask for tears and holes. 3. Find which side is the top side. If the mask has a metal strip or stiff edge, that is the top side. 4. Check that the right side of the mask is facing away from you. The colored side should face away from you. 5. Place the mask to your face. Pinch the metal strip or the stiff edge of the mask so that it molds to the shape of your nose. 6. Pull down the bottom of the mask so it covers your mouth and chin  To take off and dispose of a surgical mask: 1. Remove the elastic loops from behind your ears, while keeping the mask away from your face and clothes. This is to avoid touching potentially contaminated surfaces of the mask 2. Throw the mask away in a closed trash can right after use 3. Wash your hands with soap and water or an alcohol-based hand sanitizer after touching or throwing away the mask.    [[Would you like more information about Should I wear a face mask?]] [[Would you like more information about What are COVID-19 symptoms?]]

questionOriginal: Should people avoid products shipped from China?
questionText: Should people avoid products shipped from China?
answerOriginal: Given that the virus has spread all over the world, there is no reason to be more concerned about a product that shipped from China compared to anywhere else. Coronaviruses may be transmitted by touching a surface, but they are more likely to be transmitted through droplets. Overtime, the amount of infectious virus on a surface decreases. You can always wipe down any packages you may receive, allow a few days to pass before opening the package, and wash your hands with soap and water after touching packages.   [[Would you like more information about how long COVID-19 lives on surfaces?]]
answerText: Since the virus has spread all over the world, there is no reason to be more concerned about a product from China compared to a product shipped from somewhere else. Most cases of coronavirus spread through close contact with an infected person. It is much less likely to get it from touching a surface like a package. To be very careful, you could wipe down the package, wait for a few days before you open the package, and wash your hands with soap and water after touching the package.  [[Would you like more information about how long COVID-19 lives on surfaces?]]

questionOriginal: Can I donate blood?
questionText: Can I donate blood?
answerOriginal: Yes, as long as you are not sick and contagious. Donated blood is always needed, so if you are well and eligible, please consider donating. Blood centers, like the Red Cross, are being given guidance by CDC on how to keep donors and staff safe during this process.
answerText: You can donate blood as long as you are not sick. Donated blood is always needed. If you are well and eligible, please consider donating. The CDC (Centers for Disease Control and Prevention) is giving blood centers like the Red Cross advice on how to keep blood donors and staff safe from COVID-19.

questionOriginal: What can I do to reduce my and my family's risk of getting COVID-19?
questionText: What can I do to reduce my and my family's risk of getting COVID-19?
answerOriginal: You can reduce your risk of getting sick by staying at home as much as possibe and only going out whenever absolutely essential. If you do go out, you should try and maintain a 6 foot distance between you and other people. If you are sick, stay at home, except when getting medical care, until your doctor says you no longer have to stay home. Cover your coughs and sneezes with tissues, and throw the tissue away. Wash your hands with soap and water for at least 20 seconds, especially after blowing your nose, coughing, sneezing, using the restroom, coming home and before eating or preparing food. If you don't have soap and water, use an alcohol-based hand sanitizer that has at least 60% alcohol. ALWAYS wash your hands with soap and water if your hands are visibly dirty. Please also clean and disinfect frequently touched surfaces (e.g. tables, countertops, light switches, door knobs, cabinet handles).
answerText: You can reduce your risk of getting sick by:  1. Staying at home as much as you can. Only go out when you really need to (for groceries, for example) 2. If you do go out, keep at least 6 foot (2 meter) distance between you and other people. 3. Wash your hands with soap and water for at least 20 seconds, especially after blowing your nose, coughing, sneezing, using the restroom, coming home and before eating or makng food. ALWAYS wash your hands with soap and water if your hands are visibly dirty.  4. If you don't have soap and water, use an alcohol-based hand sanitizer that has at least 60% alcohol. 5. Clean and disinfect surfaces that people touch a lot (e.g. tables, countertops, light switches, door knobs, cabinet handles).   If you or someone in your family gets sick, stay at home, except when getting medical care, until your doctor says you no longer have to stay home. Cover your coughs and sneezes with tissues, and throw the tissue away.  [[Would you like more information about What is social distancing?]] [[Would you like more information about What if someone in my house gets sick with COVID-19?]]

questionOriginal: What if someone in my house gets sick with COVID-19?
questionText: What if someone in my house gets sick with COVID-19?
answerOriginal: Most people who get COVID-19 will be able to recover at home. If you are sick, stay at home except when you need to get medical care. If you experience difficulty breathing or shortness of breath, persistent pain or pressure in the chest, new confusion or inability to arouse, bluish lips or face, or any other concerns, please seek medical attention immediately. Please keep in mind that this is not the full list and if you're experiencing severe symptoms or something you are concerned by, please contact your medical provider.   If possible, use a separate room and bathroom for the sick household member. Try to have the sick family member maintain distance as much as possible. It will be important to make sure you clean and sanitize your hands and home regularly.  Avoid sharing personal items like utensils, foods, and drinks.
answerText: Most people who get COVID-19 will be able to recover at home. If possible, have the sick household member use a separate room and bathroom. Try to have the sick family member stay away from other people as much as they can. Clean and sanitize your hands and home regularly.  Don't share personal items like utensils, foods, and drinks.  The sick person should stay at home except to get medical care. Please contact a health care provider right away if they have one of these severe symptoms: -Trouble breathing  -Shortness of breath  -Chest pain or pressure that won't go away -Feeling very tired or unable to wake up from sleeping -Lips or face look blue  Please keep in mind that this is not the full list. If someone in your house has one of these severe symptoms or something that worries you, please contact your medical provider.

questionOriginal: What should I do if there is an outbreak in my community?
questionText: What should I do if there is an outbreak in my community?
answerOriginal: It is important to stay calm and put your preparedness plan into action. Please stay home if you are sick, and limit contact with others as much as possible (with at least a 6 feet distance between you and another person). It is important to stay informed about the local COVID-19 situation through local health department. Please continue to practice handwashing, cover your coughs and sneezes with tissue, and frequently clean high-touch surfaces with regular household detergent and water.   It is important to also notify your workplace ASAP if your regular work schedule will need to change. Ask to work from home or take leave if your or someone in your home gets sick with COVID-19 symptoms or if your child's school is dismissed.   If you live alone and have a chronic health condition, please reach out to friends, family, loved ones, and healthcare providers. Also ask them to check in on you.   Please also stay in touch with loved ones by phone or email. This can be a lonely and isolating time, so it is important to practice self-care as well as reach out to others.
answerText: If there is an outbreak in your community, you should:  1. Stay calm! 2. Stay at least 6 feet (2 meters) away from other people 3. Stay informed about the local COVID-19 situation through your local health department 4. Wash your hands 5. Cover your coughs and sneezes with tissue 6. Clean surfaces that people touch a lot  Please stay home if you are sick, and limit contact with others as much as you can.  Notify your workplace as soon as possible if your regular work schedule will need to change. Ask to work from home or take leave if your or someone in your home gets sick with COVID-19 symptoms or if your child's school is dismissed.   If you live alone and have a chronic health problem, please reach out to friends, family, loved ones, and healthcare providers. Also ask them to check in on you. Stay in touch with loved ones by phone or email. This can be a lonely and isolating time, so it is important to practice self-care as well as reach out to others. questionOriginal: Can I go outside for a walk during shutdown?
questionText: Can I go outside for a walk during shutdown?
answerOriginal: In most places, you can still go for a walk during a shelter in place order as long as you are abiding by your local state or county's rules. In general, here are a few tips:  -Stay at least 6 feet away from other people -Limit how long you will be outside, especially if there is a COVID-19 outbreak near you -Do not go to places where there are lots of people or crowds  This may not be allowed if you are in a location with strict quarantine measures. If you are or might be infected with COVID-19, you should not go for a walk outside, and should be self-isolating or in quarantine.   [[Would you like more information about What is social-distancing?]]

questionOriginal: Can COVID-19 be transmitted through food?
questionText: Can COVID-19 be transmitted through food?
answerOriginal: There is currently no evidence to suggest that food is a likley route of transmission of the virus. Scientists and food safety authorities across the world are closely monitoring the spread of COVID-19.
answerText: There is currently no evidence to suggest that food is a likely way of spreading COVID-19. Food safety experts are closely watching the spread of COVID-19.

questionOriginal: Any advice about how to minimize risk during grocery shopping trips or getting takeout.
questionText: Any advice about how to minimize risk during grocery shopping trips or getting takeout.
answerOriginal: Currently, there is no evidence of food or food packaging being associated with transmission of COVID-19. Like other viruses, it is possible that the virus that causes COVID-19 can survive on surfaces or objects. For that reason, try and disinfect the shopping cart at the grocery store, avoid touching your face while outside of your home, and wash your hands as soon as you come home with soap and water.
answerText: Like other viruses, it is possible that the virus that causes COVID-19 can stay on surfaces and objects. Here are some tips to reduce risk while grocery shopping:   1. Shop when stores are less busy 2. Disinfect the shopping cart at the grocery store  3. Stay at least 6 feet (2 meters) away from others while shopping 4. Avoid touching your face while shopping  5. While paying, avoid hand-to-hand cash transfers. Wipe down debit or credit cards after using them. 5. Wash your hands as soon as you come home with soap and water  You can also see if delivery services are available in you area. In some areas, you may be able to buy directly from local farmers and producers.  [[Would you like more information about Are there services available to help older adults get groceries?]]

questionOriginal: How long should we self-quarantine for?
questionText: How long should we self-quarantine for?
answerOriginal: You should quarantine yourself for at least 14 days, as it takes between 1-14 days for the COVID-19 symptoms to develop. Once these fourteen days have passed, you would no longer be considered to be a risk and spread the virus further. Remember, everytime you could have been exposed to the virus requires you to restart your 14 day clock for quarantine.
answerText: Quarantine means staying away from other people because you might have been exposed to the virus. For COVID-19, people should quarantine for at least 14 days, or 2 weeks from the time they might have had contact with someone with COVID-19. That's because most people who get COVID-19 would have symptoms within 14 days.   Scientists think that people are not likely to spread COVID-19 to others if they do not get sick after 14 days. Remember, every time you could have been exposed to the virus means you should restart your 14 day clock for quarantine.  [[Would you like more information about What is the difference between isolation and quarantine?]]

questionOriginal: Should I use soap and water or a hand sanitizer to protect against COVID-19?
questionText: Should I use soap and water or a hand sanitizer to protect against COVID-19?
answerOriginal: Handwashing with soap and water for at least 20 seconds is the best way to protect yourself and your family from getting sick! This is important to do regularly - every time you wash your hands - but especially after blowing your nose, coughing, sneezing, going to the restroom, and before eating or preparing food. If you do not have soap and water available, please use an alcohol based hand sanitizer that has at least 60% alcohol.
answerText: Washing your hands with soap and water for at least 20 seconds is the best way to protect yourself and your family from getting sick! Wash your hands regularly, especially after blowing your nose, coughing, sneezing, going to the restroom, and before eating or preparing food. If you do not have soap and water, use an alcohol based hand sanitizer that has at least 60% alcohol.  [[Would you like more information about How can I protect myself and others?]]

questionOriginal: How long does the virus stay in paper money and coins?
questionText: How long does the virus stay in paper money and coins?
answerOriginal: It can be detected for up to four hours copper (similar to coins) and up to 24 hours on cardboard (similar to paper) in a laboratory setting. It is unclear how long it can last in real world settings. It is best to wash your hands frequently after handling objects outside of your home.   [[Would you like more information about how long COVID-19 lives on surfaces?]]
answerText: We don't know for sure how long the virus can last on coins and paper money. In laboratory studies, scientists found that it could last up to 4 hours on copper (similar to coins) and up to 24 hours on cardboard (similar to paper). It is unclear how long the virus can last on surfaces in the real world. It is best to wash your hands well after handling money.  [[Would you like more information about how long COVID-19 lives on surfaces?]]

questionOriginal: Does the virus stay on clothing?
questionText: Does the virus stay on clothing?
answerOriginal: While researchers found that the virus can remain on some surfaces for up to 72 hours, the study didn’t include fabric. It is best to have a pair of outside clothes you wear on errands and remove them as soon as you come in the house and wash clothes frequently.   [[Would you like more information about how long COVID-19 lives on surfaces?]]

questionOriginal: How do I take care of those infected with COVID-19?
questionText: How do I take care of those infected with COVID-19?
answerOriginal: If you are caring for someone with COVID-19 at home, prevent the spread of germs, treat symptoms, and monitor for emergency signs.  You can prevent the spread of germs at home by having the person stay in one room, away from other people (including yourself), as much as possible. Avoid having visitors and restrict contact with other people and pets. Avoid sharing personal household items like dishes and towels and have them use a separate bathroom if possible. If the person needs to be around other people, they should wear a facemask if available. If facemasks are available but they are unable to wear one, you should wear one when you need to be in the same room.   Prevent the spread of germs by washing your hands often with soap and water for at least 20 seconds, especially after interacting with the sick person. If soap and water are not readily available, use a hand sanitizer that contains at least 60% alcohol. Always avoid touching your eyes, nose, and mouth.  Clean and disinfect all surfaces that are touched often, like tabletops and doorknobs, using household cleaning sprays or wipes. If laundry is soiled, wear disposable gloves and keep soiled laundry away from your body while laundering.   Symptoms of COVID-19 can be managed by staying hydrated and resting. For most people, symptoms last a few days and get better after a week. Keep track of symptoms (especially fevers) and contact the person’s healthcare provider if they are getting sicker. In the case of an emergency, call 911 and tell the dispatch personnel that the person has or might have COVID-19.
answerText: If you are caring for someone with COVID-19 at home, prevent the spread of germs, treat symptoms, and monitor for emergency signs.   1. Prevent the spread. If possible, have the sick household member use a separate room and bathroom. Have the sick person stay away from other people and pets as much as they can.  Don't share personal items like towels, dishes, and food. If the person needs to be around other people, they should wear a facemask. If they cannot wear a facemask, others should wear one while in the same room. The sick person should stay at home except to get medical care.   To protect yourself, avoid touching your eyes, nose, and mouth. Disinfect all surfaces that are touched often, like tabletops and doorknobs, using cleaning sprays or wipes. If laundry is soiled, wear disposable gloves and keep laundry away from your body while washing. Wash your hands frequently with soap and water for at least 20 seconds or use alcohol-based hand sanitizer that is at least 60% alcohol.    2. Treat symptoms. Most people  with COVID-19 can get better with rest and drinking plenty of fluids. Symptoms usually last a few days and get better after a week. Keep track of symptoms, especially fevers.   3. Monitor for emergency signs. Contact a health care provider right away if they have one of these severe symptoms: -Trouble breathing  -Shortness of breath  -Chest pain or pressure that won't go away -Feeling very tired or unable to wake up from sleeping -Lips or face look blue  If someone in your house has one of these severe symptoms or something that worries you, please contact your medical provider. In the case of an emergency, call 911 and tell the dispatcher that the person has or might have COVID-19.  [[Would you like more information about What are COVID-19 symptoms?]] [[Would you like more information about Who is at higher risk of severe illness?]]

questionOriginal: Will ingesting soap bubbles kill COVID-19 in my lungs?
questionText: Will ingesting soap bubbles kill COVID-19 in my lungs?
answerOriginal: No, ingesting soap will not kill COVID-19 in your lungs. Trying to ingest or inhale soap could actually cause more damage to your lungs.

questionOriginal: Does a mask actually help if I am sick or not?
questionText: Does a mask actually help if I am sick or not?
answerOriginal: A significant portion of people with coronavirus do not show symptoms, and the virus can spread between people even if they do not currently show symptoms. Because of this, the CDC recommends wearing cloth face masks in public settings to slow the spread of the virus so individuals who are sick but do not realize it do not spread the virus to those that are healthy.   [[Would you like more information about Should I wear a face mask?]] [[Would you like more information about how do I sew a face mask?]] [[Would you like more information about How do you put on, use, take off, and dispose of a face mask?]]
answerText: The virus can spread between people even if they do not have symptoms or feel ill. Because of this, the CDC (Centers for Disease Control and Prevention) recommends wearing cloth face masks in public. This can help to slow the spread of the virus so that people who are sick but do not realize it do not spread the virus to healthy people.  [[Would you like more information about Should I wear a face mask?]] [[Would you like more information about how do I sew a face mask?]] [[Would you like more information about How do you put on, use, take off, and dispose of a face mask?]]

questionOriginal: Can I move in with family if we have all been symptom free for 14 days?
questionText: Can I move in with family if we have all been symptom free for 14 days?
answerOriginal: Everyone situation is different, which will influence whether you can move in with family. You should talk to your health provider to discuss whether it is relatively safe for you to move in with you family. Here are a few questions to consider discussing with your provider :  - Is your current home unsafe or uninhabitable?  - Is COVID-19 spreading in the area where you’re going?  - Will you be in close contact with others during your trip?  - Are you or the people you are moving with more likely to get severe illness if you get COVID-19?  - Will you live with someone who is older or has a serious, chronic medical condition?  - Is everyone you are moving in with practicing recommended social distancing or self-isolation guidelines?

Is your current home unsafe or unfit to live in?  2. Is COVID-19 spreading in the area where you’re going?  3. Will you be in close contact with others while you travel?  4. Are you or the people you will be living with with more likely to get severe illness if you get COVID-19?  5. Will you live with someone who is older or has a serious, chronic health problem?  6. Is everyone you are moving in with following the social distancing or self-isolation guidelines? questionOriginal: I worry about my mental health during quarantine, what can I do to help it?
questionText: I worry about my mental health during quarantine, what can I do to help it?
answerOriginal: If you are worried about your mental health during this time, you are not alone. If you are concerned that you may be at risk of harming yourself or someone else you know, please call 911 or the equivalent emergency services in your country.   Here are some ways to cope with stress that some people find helpful: 1. Take breaks from watching, reading, or listening to news stories. 2. Take breaks from social media. 3. Take care of your body by trying to eat healthy meals, exercising at home, and avoiding alcohol and drugs. 4. Make time to unwind and do activities you enjoy. 5. Spend time talking to others, while practicing social distancing. If you have a phone or Internet access, call someone you trust and talk to them about how you are feeling.  If you are feeling overwhelmed by sadness, depression, or anxiety, please seek help from a trusted provider. If you have a mental health condition please continue your treatment. If you want or plan to harm yourself or others, please call an emergency number or hotline.

If you want or plan to harm yourself or others, please call an emergency number or hotline.

questionOriginal: Should I go to the ER or my physician directly if I'm infected?
questionText: Should I go to the ER or my physician directly if I'm infected?
answerOriginal: If you believe you have COVID-19, please contact your health provider. If you are showing emergency symptoms, please call an emergency number or go to the emergency room. Be sure to tell the dispatcher if you have or think you have COVID-19. Mild symptoms of COVID-19 can be managed at home; your healthcare provider will help you determine if you should be tested and if your symptoms are mild enough to be safe at home.
answerText: If you believe you have COVID-19, please contact your health provider. Your healthcare provider will help you determine if you should be tested and if your symptoms are mild enough to be safe at home. Most people with mild symptoms of COVID-19 can get better at home. If this is not an emergency, this symptom checker by the Centers for Disease Control (CDC) can help you find out if you could have COVID-19. It can also help you decide what to do next. https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/symptoms-testing/index.html  If you have one of these symptoms, you should call 911 or emergency medical services to seek care right away and tell the dispatcher that you think you have COVID-19:  -Trouble breathing -Pain or pressure in the chest that won't go away -Feeling confused -Lips or face that look blue   [[Would you like more information about What are COVID-19 symptoms? ]]

questionOriginal: What are other options to sanitize surfaces if I don't have soap and water?
questionText: What are other options to sanitize surfaces if I don't have soap and water?
answerOriginal: If you do not have soap and water, you may sanitize surfaces using a household disinfectant. Alcohol solutions that contain at least 70% alcohol may also be used. Please be sure to follow instructions on the product's label.  You may also be able to use a diluted bleach solution, depending on the surface you want to clean. Check the label to make sure you can use the solution for disinfecting and that it is not expired. Follow the instructions on the label and leave the solution on the surface for at least 1 minute. Please do NOT mix household bleach with ammonia or any other cleanser.

Check the label to make sure you can use the solution for disinfecting and that it is not expired. Follow the instructions on the label. Leave the solution on the surface for at least 1 minute. Do NOT mix bleach with ammonia or any other cleaner.  [[Would you like more information about How long does COVID-19 live on surfaces?]]

questionOriginal: How do I quarantine myself if I live with my family or roommates?
questionText: How do I quarantine myself if I live with my family or roommates?
answerOriginal: If you or someone you live with is infected, or at high risk of being infected, you should stay in another room as much as you can and use a separate bedroom and bathroom if possible. questionOriginal: Should someone continue to self-isolate even if they are feeling better?
questionText: Should someone continue to self-isolate even if they are feeling better?
answerOriginal: If you have symptoms of coronavirus, you'll need to self-isolate for 7 days. After 7 days, you no longer need to self-isolate if you do not have a high temperature. If you still have a temperature, keep self-isolating until your temperature is back to normal. You do not need to self-isolate if your only symptom after 7 days is a cough, because a cough can last for several weeks after the infection is gone.  If you live with someone with symptoms of COVID-19, you should self-isolate for 14 days starting the day their symptoms started. If more than one person at home has symptoms, self-isolate for 14 days starting the day the first person's symptoms started. If you get symptoms, self-isolate for 7 days starting when your symptoms began, even if this is longer than the original 14 days. If you do not get symptoms, you can stop self-isolating after 14 days.
answerText: If you have symptoms of coronavirus, you'll need to self-isolate for 7 days. After 7 days, you no longer need to self-isolate if you do not have a high temperature. If you still have a temperature, keep self-isolating until your temperature is back to normal. You do not need to self-isolate if your only symptom after 7 days is a cough, because a cough can last for several weeks after the infection is gone.  If you live with someone with symptoms of COVID-19, you should self-isolate for 14 days starting the day their symptoms started. If more than one person at home has symptoms, self-isolate for 14 days starting the day the first person's symptoms started. If you get symptoms, self-isolate for 7 days starting when your symptoms began, even if this is longer than the original 14 days. If you do not get symptoms, you can stop self-isolating after 14 days.

questionOriginal: Is it safe to use ride-sharing services (e.g. Lyft, Uber)?
questionText: Is it safe to use ride-sharing services (e.g. Lyft, Uber)?

questionOriginal: How do I take my temperature?
questionText: How do I take my temperature?
answerOriginal: Your body temperature can be measured in many places on your body. The most common ones are the mouth, the ear, the armpit, and the rectum. If you are able to take an oral temperature (which uses a thermometer in your mouth), this is the best method for adults to take an accurate temperature.   To take your temperature using a digital thermometer, place the tip of the thermometer in your mouth, under the tongue and close to the middle. Keep the lips firmly closed and hold the thermometer in place with his tongue and fingers without biting it. Based on the thermometer type, you will hear a beep in about 30 seconds or some other indication you can take the thermometer out. Take the thermometer out and read the temperature.  In most adults, a fever is an oral temperature above 100.4°F (38°C).
answerText: You can take your body temperature a few different ways. The most common ones are the mouth, the ear, the armpit, and the rectum. The best way for adults is orally, which uses a thermometer in your mouth. This is the most accurate way.  To take your temperature using a digital thermometer:  1. Place the tip of the thermometer in your mouth, under the tongue and close to the middle.  2. Keep your lips closed and hold the thermometer in place with your tongue and fingers. Don't bite it.  3. Based on the thermometer type, you will hear a beep in about 30 seconds or some other signal. You can take the thermometer out.  4. Take the thermometer out and read the temperature.  In most adults, a fever is an oral temperature above 100.4°F (38°C).   [[Would you like more information about What is self-monitoring?]]

questionOriginal: Can you use any soap to wash your hands?
questionText: Can you use any soap to wash your hands?
answerOriginal: You can use bar soap or liquid soap to wash your hands. Studies have not found any added health benefit from using soaps containing antibacterial ingredients when compared with plain soap. Both are equally effective in getting rid of germs as long as you use the appropriate technique for handwashing.
answerText: You can use bar soap or liquid soap to wash your hands. Both work just as well to get rid of germs as long as you wash your hands the right way. Studies have not found that antibacterials soaps work any better than plain soap.  [[Would you like more information about Does hand-washing kill the virus?]] [[Should I use soap and water or a hand sanitizer to protect against COVID-19?]]

questionOriginal: Can I move during a pandemic?
questionText: Can I move during a pandemic?
answerOriginal: You should check with your moving company and local officials to see if there are travel or group restrictions that would prevent you from moving.  While you may be allowed to move during COVID-19, please consider the following things to determine whether it is in your best interest:  - Is your current home unsafe or uninhabitable?  - Is COVID-19 spreading in the area where you’re going?  - Will you be in close contact with others during your trip?  - Are you or the people you are moving with more likely to get severe illness if you get COVID-19?  - Do you live with someone who is older or has a serious, chronic medical condition?  If moving is essential, these same questions can help you plan your relocation to be as safe as possible. If you plan to move in with someone, consider talking to your healthcare provider to see if its safe for you to move at this time.

questionOriginal: How do I clean and disinfect linens, clothing, and other items that go in the laundry?
questionText: How do I clean and disinfect linens, clothing, and other items that go in the laundry?
answerOriginal: Wear gloves when handling dirty laundry from an ill person and then discard after each use. If using reusable gloves, those gloves should be only used for cleaning and disinfecting surfaces for COVID-19 and should not be used for other household purposes. Clean hands right after gloves are removed. If no gloves are used when handling dirty laundry, be sure to wash hands afterwards. If possible, do not shake dirty laundry. This will minimize the chance of dispersing virus through the air. Launder items as appropriate in accordance with the manufacturer’s instructions. If possible, launder items using the warmest appropriate water setting for the items and dry items completely. Dirty laundry from an ill person can be washed with other people’s items. Clean and disinfect clothes hampers according to guidance above for surfaces. If possible, consider placing a bag liner that is either disposable (can be thrown away) or can be laundered.

questionText: Will healthcare workers be more isolated because they are exposed to the virus on a daily basis?

questionOriginal: Should I visit my parents in a senior home?
questionText: Should I visit my parents in a senior home?
answerOriginal: You should not visit a senior home and it is likely that senior homes are not allowing visitors at this time. This is because a lot of people at the senior home are probably at high risk due to age and underlying health conditions. You might be able to talk with your family over the phone or with a video call. For other information or options, you should contact the senior home to find out how they are handling the COVID-19 response and how you can talk to your family.

questionOriginal: What can I do during quarantine?
questionText: What can I do during quarantine?
answerOriginal: Most people are not used to being at home all the time. Many people feel bored or unsure of what to do during quarantine. Some things to do during quarantine include:  -reading (e-books and audiobooks are good options if you do not have physical books at home) -finding a new hobby, like an art project -learning to cook a new meal -talking on the phone or having video calls with friends or family  If it is allowed in your area, you may be able to go for walks outside as long as you practice social distancing. Experts also recommend having a set routine during the day, such as having set mealtimes and bedtimes.

questionOriginal: Can vodka be used as a hand sanitizer?
questionText: Can vodka be used as a hand sanitizer?
answerOriginal: Vodka typically does not include enough alcohol to be an effective hand sanitizer. Make sure any hand santizer you have has at least 60% alcohol, as recommended by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. Any hand sanitizer that has less than 60% alcohol will not be effective at killing the virus.   If you don't have access to hand sanitizer, soap and water are always the best option.

questionOriginal: What are COVID-19 symptoms?
questionText: What are COVID-19 symptoms?
answerOriginal: The most common symptoms of COVID-19 are fever, feeling tired, and dry cough. Some patients may also have aches and pains, stuffy nose, runny nose, sore throat, or diarrhea.  Most people have mild symptoms that get worse slowly. Most people start to feel sick between 1 and 14 days after being exposed to COVID-19.Some people get infected but don't feel sick at all.   Older people (those who are 65 or older) and people with health problems like diabetes, high blood pressure, or heart problems are more likely to get very sick from COVID-19.   If you or someone you know has one of these problems, you should call a doctor or go to the emergency room RIGHT NOW:  -Pain or pressure in the chest that doesn't go away  -Starting to feel confused  -Can't wake up from sleeping  -Lips or face look blue   If someone has one of these severe symptoms, they need care right away.   [[Would you like more information about Who is at a higher risk for severe illness?]]

questionOriginal: Is COVID-19 the same as the flu?
questionText: Is COVID-19 the same as the flu?
answerOriginal: The symptoms of COVID-19 and flu are very similar. Both can cause fever, cough, and shortness of breath. To know for sure if you have COVID-19, you will need to get tested. questionOriginal: What should I do if I think I was exposed to someone with COVID?
questionText: What should I do if I think I was exposed to someone with COVID?
answerOriginal: If you think you had contact with someone with COVID-19, you should quarantine yourself for at least 14 days (or two weeks) so that you don't spread the disease. Most people who get sick from COVID-19 get symptoms 1 to 14 days after being exposed. If you have any symptoms related to COVID-19, you should self-isolate and talk to your health care provider.  [[Would you like more information about What is self-quarantine?]] [[Would you like more information about What are Covid-19 symptoms?]] [[Would you like more information about What is self-isolation?]]

questionOriginal: Who is at a higher risk of severe illness?
questionText: Who is at a higher risk of severe illness?
answerOriginal: People are more likely to get a severe case of COVID-19 if they are:  -Older than 65 years old -Living in a nursing home or long term care facility -Pregnant -In a prison or jail  People are also more likely to get a severe case if they have a health problem such as:  -Lung disease -Asthma -Diabetes -Sickle cell disease -Liver cirrhosis (liver scarring) -Recent chemotherapy -A weaker immune system   [[Would you like more information about Who is at a higher risk of getting COVID-19?]]

questionOriginal: Who is at a higher risk of getting COVID-19?
questionText: Who is at a higher risk of getting COVID-19?
answerOriginal: You could be at higher risk of catching COVID-19 if many people have gotten COVID-19 near where you live. You could also have a higher risk if you visit places where many people are getting sick with COVID-19.  Right now, in most places, the risk of catching COVID-19 is still low. But this is changing quickly in many cities and areas around the world.  [[Would you like more information about Who is at a higher risk of severe illness?]]

questionOriginal: Where do I go if I have mild symptoms?
questionText: Where do I go if I have mild symptoms?
answerOriginal: If you only have mild symptoms, it is safest to stay home. Most people with mild symptoms from COVID-19 are able to recover at home without medical care.  To keep the virus from spreading, you should: -Avoid public areas -Stay home, except to get medical care -If you think you need to go to the clinic or hospital, call before you go.    If you get one of these severe symptoms, you should call a doctor or go to the emergency room RIGHT NOW:  -Pain or pressure in the chest that doesn't go away -Starting to feel confused -Lips or face look blue

questionOriginal: Can my child get sick from COVID-19?
questionText: Can my child get sick from COVID-19?
answerOriginal: From what doctors know now, children are not at a higher risk of Covid-19 than adults. Children can become sick with it, but not as often as adults. Most children who have gotten sick with COVID-19 have had mild symptoms, like fever, runny nose, and cough. Some have also had vomiting and diarrhea.  We are still learning if children with some underlying medical conditions may have a higher risk.  [[Would you like more information about how can I protect my child from COVID-19?]] [[Would you like more information about Who is at a higher risk of severe illness?]]

questionOriginal: How can I protect my child from COVID-19?
questionText: How can I protect my child from COVID-19?
answerOriginal: By having them practice the same things you have to do! Washing hands with soap and water for at least 20 seconds, avoiding people who are sick, cleaning and disinfecting high touch surfaces in household common areas (e.g. tables, chairs, doorknobs, etc.), and laundering items like plush toys. It is also important to that your children try and socially distance from other individuals outside of your household. This means you should avoid playdates, allowing kids to get together physically with friends or playing on jungle gyms in public playgrounds.    [[Would you like more information about how do I prepare my child for a COVID-19 outbreak?]]
answerText: You can protect your child by having them wash hands with soap and water for at least 20 seconds and avoid people who are sick. They should also stay away from people outside your home. This means you should avoid playdates, playing on public playgrounds, or being physically close to friends.  You should also clean and disinfect surfaces that you touch a lot in household common areas like tables, chairs, and doorknobs. Wash clothes and plush toys frequently.  [[Would you like more information about how do I prepare my child for a COVID-19 outbreak?]] [[Would you like more information about How can I protect myself and others?]]

questionOriginal: Are symptoms of COVID-19 different in children?
questionText: Are symptoms of COVID-19 different in children?
answerOriginal: No. They have the same symptoms, though it may be milder in children. Reported symptoms include cold-like symptoms, such as fever, runny nose, and cough. Vomiting and diarrhea have also been reported. There is more to be learned about how COVID-19 affects children.  [[Would you like more information about how can i protect my child from COVID-19?]] [[Would you like more information about how do I prepare my child for a COVID-19 outbreak?]]
answerText: Children and adults have the same COVID19 symptoms, although children might not get as sick as adults. Children might get a fever, runny nose, or cough. Some children have had vomiting or diarrhea. We are still learning about how COVID-19 affects children.  [[Would you like more information about how can i protect my child from COVID-19?]] [[Would you like more information about how do I prepare my child for a COVID-19 outbreak?]]

questionOriginal: Should children wear masks?
questionText: Should children wear masks?
answerOriginal: Children under the age of 2 should not wear any type of masks. Because babies' airways are smaller, breathing through a mask is even harder on them and using a mask could increase the risk of suffocation. Older infants or young toddlers are not likely to keep the mask on and will likely try to remove it frequently; this will mean they are touching their face more and could infect themselves with the virus. The best course of action is to keep children at home and socialy distanced.   [[Would you like more information about how can I protect my child from COVID-19?]]
answerText: Children under the age of 2 years should not wear any type of masks. Because babies' airways are smaller, breathing through a mask is even harder on them and they are more likely to suffocate if they use a mask. Older infants or young toddlers are not likely to keep the mask on and will likely try to remove it. This will mean they are touching their face more and could infect themselves with the virus. It is safest to keep children at home and follow social distancing.  [[Would you like more information about how can I protect my child from COVID-19?]] [[What is social distancing?]]

questionOriginal: Can I take my child to the playground?
questionText: Can I take my child to the playground?
answerOriginal: It is currently recommended to avoid if possible - as there are many germs at playgrounds. Your children can still play outside, but make sure they avoid gathering in large groups (more than 10 people), and that they wash their hands with soap and water for at least twenty seconds.   [[Would you like more information about how can I protect my child from COVID-19?]] [[Would you like more information about how do I prepare my child for a COVID-19 outbreak?]]

Children can still play outside, but they should not be in large groups (more than 10 people). They should wash their hands with soap and water for at least twenty seconds.   [[Would you like more information about how can I protect my child from COVID-19?]] [[Would you like more information about how do I prepare my child for a COVID-19 outbreak?]]

questionOriginal: How do I prepare my child for a COVID-19 outbreak?
questionText: How do I prepare my child for a COVID-19 outbreak?
answerOriginal: It is important to talk with your child about what's going on. This is a stressful time for both children and adults, and children definitely will have questions. Talk to them about the outbreak, stay calm, and what you are doing as a family to stay safe.
answerText: It is important to talk with your child about what is going on. This is a hard time and children will have questions. Stay calm, talk to them about the outbreak, and tell them what you are doing as a family to stay safe.

questionOriginal: Why are schools closing down because of COVID-19?
questionText: Why are schools closing down because of COVID-19?
answerOriginal: School closings are a way that can help slow the spread of and reduce exposure to COVID-19. Please keep up with local news media sources, as they will share information about school dismissals. If schools are dismissed, your child should stay home and avoid gathering or socializing anywhere (like a friend's house, favorite restaurants, or local shopping malls). The purpose of closing schools down is to prevent students from silently passing the virus to each other, and then having students pass it to their families.   [[Would you like more information about How do I prepare my child for a COVID-19 outbreak?]] [[Would you like more information about How can I protect my child from COVID-19?]]
answerText: Closing schools helps to slow the spread COVID-19. The purpose of closing schools is to prevent students from passing the virus to each other, and then having students pass it to their families. Please keep up with local news media sources, as they will share news about school closures. If schools are closed, your child should stay home. They should avoid groups of people and avoid visiting friends or public places.  [[Would you like more information about How do I prepare my child for a COVID-19 outbreak?]] [[Would you like more information about How can I protect my child from COVID-19?]]

questionOriginal: Are children immune to COVID-19?
questionText: Are children immune to COVID-19?
answerOriginal: Currently, it is thought that children can acquire the virus at the same rates as adults, however, there symptoms are usually much milder. Some kids and infants have been sick with COVID-19, but it is still adults who make up most of the cases we are seeing today. If a child gets COVID-19, their symptoms are going to be similar to the symptoms adults get. This includes: cold-like symptoms like fever, runny nose, and cough. Vomiting and diarrhea are also possible.   [[Would you like more information about how can I protect my child from COVID-19?]]
answerText: Right now, most experts think that children can get the virus at the same rates as adults. But children usually don't get as sick as adults. If a child gets COVID-19, their symptoms are going to be similar to the symptoms adults get. These include fever, runny nose, and cough. Vomiting and diarrhea are also possible.   [[Would you like more information about how can I protect my child from COVID-19?]] [[Would you like more information about What are COVID-19 symptoms?]]

questionOriginal: What actions should businesses take to prepare for community spread of COVID-19?
questionText: What actions should businesses take to prepare for community spread of COVID-19?
answerOriginal: Employers should consider following strategies to prevent spread of illness: • Encourage sick employees to stay home.  Ensure consistency of policies with public health guidance. • Separate employees with respiratory illness. • Clean frequently touched surfaces. • Provide information to employees before traveling

questionOriginal: Am I at greater risk of adverse COVID-19 outcomes if I am pregnant?
questionText: Am I at greater risk of adverse COVID-19 outcomes if I am pregnant?
answerOriginal: Doctors don't yet know for sure if pregnant women have a higher risk of having severe symptoms or long-term effects if they get COVID-19. But it is always important for pregnant women to protect themselves from getting sick. Proper hygiene such as washing hands can help reduce the risk of getting infected of spreading the virus to others.  If you are pregnant and concerned about COVID-19, talk to your doctor.  [[Would you like more information about What can I do to prevent getting COVID-19?]]

But it is always important for pregnant women to protect themselves from getting sick.
