questionOriginal: What do I do if I've tested positive for COVID-19 and am about to deliver?
questionText: What do I do if I've tested positive for COVID-19 and am about to deliver?
answerOriginal: If you've tested positive for COVID-19 and are pregnant - it is important that you notify the obstetric unit and hospital prior to your arrival. This is so that the healthcare facility can prepare for your arrival and make all necessary preparations to keep you and your baby as safe as possible.  [[Would you like more information about What precautions I shoudl take if I am going to the hospital for delivery?]]
answerText: If you've have COVID-19 and are pregnant, tell the obstetric unit and hospital before you go there. This is so that they can prepare to keep you and your baby as safe as they can.  [[Would you like more information about What precautions I shoudl take if I am going to the hospital for delivery?]]

questionOriginal: Can pregnant women with COVID-19 pass the virus to their fetus or newborn?
questionText: Can pregnant women with COVID-19 pass the virus to their fetus or newborn?
answerOriginal: No evidences show that virus can pass from mother to fetus before delivery. A report looked at nine pregnant women in China in their third trimester with pneumonia caused by COVID-19. None of the mothers developed severe illness. Two babies did show some signs of distress, but all nine babies were born alive and healthy. Also, they all tested negative for coronavirus.
answerText: No evidences show that virus can pass from mother to fetus before delivery. A report looked at nine pregnant women in China in their third trimester with pneumonia caused by COVID-19. None of the mothers developed severe illness. Two babies did show some signs of distress, but all nine babies were born alive and healthy. Also, they all tested negative for coronavirus.

questionOriginal: Can my pet (dog, cat, other animal) get COVID-19?
questionText: Can my pet (dog, cat, other animal) get COVID-19?
answerOriginal: There has not been clear evidence of the virus passing from humans to their pets at home. However, there was a tiger in a zoo in New York city that seems to have been infected with COVID-19 from it's caretakers. So it is important to always wash your hands before and after interacting with animals. The amount of information we know about human to animal transmission may change so talk to your pet's doctor if you want more information or are concerned about your pet's health.   Until we know more, if you have been diagnosed with COVID-19 and have a pet or other animal: avoid close contact with them, do not snuggle or kiss them, or let them lick you, sit on your lap, or sleep in your bed, practice good cough etiquette, avoid coughing and sneezing on your animals, have another member of your household care for your animals (if this is not possible, always wash your hands before touching or feeding them), and limit your animal's contact with other people and animals (this may mean keeping them indoors).
answerText: Right now, we don't know of any clear cases of the virus passing from people to their pets. There was a tiger in a zoo in New York City that seems to have gotten COVID-19 from its caretakers. To be safe, wash your hands before and after touching animals.   Until we know more, if you have been diagnosed with COVID-19 and have a pet or other animal, you should:  1. Avoid close contact with them. Do not snuggle or kiss them, let them lick you, sit on your lap, or sleep in your bed. 2. Avoid coughing and sneezing on your animals. Cover your coughs and sneezes. 3. Have another member of your household care for your animals, if you can. 4. If it's not possible to have someone else care for your animal, always wash your hands before touching or feeding them. 5. Limit your animal's contact with other people and animals. Tthis may mean keeping them indoors.  We might learn more about human to animal spread in the future. Talk to your pet's doctor if you are worried about your pet's health.

sourceName: JHU Public Health Canada Public Health Services
questionOriginal: Can I get COVID-19 from animals when travelling to other countries?
questionText: Can I get COVID-19 from animals when travelling to other countries?
answerOriginal: Although the current spread and growth of the COVID-19 outbreak is primarily associated with spread from person to person, experts agree that the virus likely originated from bats and may have passed through an intermediary animal source in China before being transmitted to humans.  It is recommended that individuals who travel to avoid contact with animals, including wild meat and wet (live animal) markets.  If you are considering travel, check the latest travel health notices for the most up-to-date travel advice prior to travelling.  Importers, rescue organizations and adoptive families should limit or postpone importing animals from affected areas. If animals are imported from an affected area: they should be closely monitored for signs of illness, you should contact a veterinarian if they become sick, and call ahead to ensure they are aware of the circumstances
answerText: Right now, COVID-19 mostly spreads from person to person. But experts agree that the virus likely came from bats and may have passed through another type of animal in China before spreading to people. If you are going to travel, check the latest health notices for up-to-date advice before you leave. Avoid contact with animals, including wild meat and live animal markets.  Animal importers, rescues, and adoptive families should limit or postpone importing animals from affected areas. If animals are imported from an affected area, monitor them closely for illness. Call a veterinarian if they get sick and call before bringing them to the office so that they can prepare.  [[Would you like more information about Should I avoid traveling?]]
ID: JHU Public Health Canada Public Health Services|||-1698955972690993672

questionOriginal: What should I do if my pet or other animals seem ill and I think it might be COVID-19?

In order to be sure the vet is ready for your pet, you should call ahead and arrange the hospital or clinic visit. Follow the animal hospital’s advice on proper safety before coming in.

questionOriginal: Is it true that veterinarians cannot get supplies like surgical gowns, gloves and masks?
questionText: Is it true that veterinarians cannot get supplies like surgical gowns, gloves and masks?
answerOriginal: Personal protective equipment (PPE) for human healthcare professionals is very important. PPE is needed in person to person settings, and may cause a lack in other health care settings.

questionOriginal: Should I avoid traveling?
questionText: Should I avoid traveling?
answerOriginal: If you are thinking about traveling, check the latest travel health notices for the most up-to-date travel advice before you go. It is important to limit travel as much as possible.   If you think you need to travel, please go through these questions:   1. Is COVID-19 spreading in the area where you're going?  If it is, you may be more likely to get infected if you travel there than if you stay at home.   2. Will you or the people who you are traveling with be in close contact with others during your trip?  Your risk increases in crowded settings, especially closed-in settings that do not have good circulation. This includes conferences, concerts, etc.   3. Are you or your travel companion more likely to get severe illness if you get COVID-19?  People at higher risk for severe disease are older adults and people of any age with serious chronic medical conditions (e.g. heart disease, lung disease, diabetes). If you are at higher risk, avoid all cruise travel and non-essential air travel.   4. Do you have a plan for taking time off from work or school, in case you are told to stay home for 14 days for self-monitoring or if you get sick with COVID-19?  You may be asked to take time off, and be unable to go to work or school until you are considered non-infectious.   5. Do you live with someone who is older or has a serious, chronic medical condition?  If you get sick with COVID-19 while you travel, your family, friends, loved ones may be at risk of getting sick. People who are older and who have health problems are more likely to get very sick.  6. Is COVID-19 spreading where I live when I return from travel?  Even if you don't feel sick right now, you could pass on COVID-19 to others during travel without knowing it. This is very important if you'll be in contact with people who are older adults or have a severe chronic health problem. These people are at higher risk of getting very sick.   It is important to go through these questions to decide if it makes sense to travel.  [[Would you like more information about Who is at a higher risk of severe illness?]] [[Would you like more information about Is there Covid in my area?]]

questionOriginal: What should I do if I just returned from a trip?
questionText: What should I do if I just returned from a trip?
answerOriginal: If you do not have any symptoms, you will be asked to do the following:  1. Self-quarantine for 14 days upon your return home.  2. Do not have any visitors, especially older adults, or those with medical conditions who are higher risk of developing serious illness. 3. Monitor your health for fever, cough, or difficulty breathing. 4. Wash you hand frequently with soap and water for at least 20 seconds, or use an alcohol based hand sanitizer. 5. Cover your mouth and nose with your arm or a tissue when coughing or sneezing. Dispose of tissue immediately, and wash your hands.   If you start to exhibit symptoms (e.g. cough, fever) within the 14 days:  1. Continue to self-isolate yourself from others.  2. Call a healthcare professional or a public health authority and describe your symptoms and travel history. Follow their instructions carefully.  3.  If your symptoms are severe - such as persistent pain/pressure in chest, difficulty breathing, new confusion or inability to arouse, or bluish lips or face, seek immediate medical attention. Please contact your medical provider if you have questions about your own health and safety.
answerText: If you do not have any symptoms, you will be asked to:  1. Self-quarantine for 14 days after you get home.  2. Do not have any visitors, especially older adults, or those with health problems who are higher risk of severe illness. 3. Monitor your health for fever, cough, or trouble breathing. 4. Wash your hands frequently with soap and water for at least 20 seconds, or use an alcohol based hand sanitizer that is at least 60% alcohol. 5. Cover your mouth and nose with your arm or a tissue when coughing or sneezing. Throw away the tissue right after and wash your hands.   If you start to have symptoms like a cough or fever within the 14 days:  1. Continue to self-isolate from others.  2. Call a healthcare professional or a public health authority and tell them your symptoms and travel history. Follow their instructions.  3.  If your symptoms are severe - such as pain or pressure in the chest that won't go away, trouble breathing, feeling confused or unable to arouse, or lips or face that look blue, seek medical care right away. Please contact your medical provider if you have questions about your health and safety.   [[Would you like more information about What is self-quarantine?]] [[Would you like more information about What are COVID-19 symptoms?]] [[Would you like more information about Who is at a higher risk of severe illness?]]

questionOriginal: What if my family member traveled from a country or had a layover in a country with widespread or sustained transmission in the last 14 days?
questionText: What if my family member traveled from a country or had a layover in a country with widespread or sustained transmission in the last 14 days?
answerOriginal: Your family member should:  Seek medical care right away. Before they go to a doctor’s office or emergency room, call ahead and tell them about their recent travel and symptoms. Avoid contact with others. Not travel while sick. They should cover their mouth and nose with a tissue or their sleeve (not their hands) when coughing or sneezing. Wash hands often with soap and water for 15-20 seconds. Use an alcohol-based hand sanitizer with at least 60% alcohol if soap and water are not available.
answerText: Your family member should:  Seek medical care right away. Before they go to a doctor’s office or emergency room, call ahead and tell them about their recent travel and symptoms. Avoid contact with others. Not travel while sick. They should cover their mouth and nose with a tissue or their sleeve (not their hands) when coughing or sneezing. questionOriginal: Can i go to the funeral of someone who died of COVID-19?
questionText: Can i go to the funeral of someone who died of COVID-19?
answerOriginal: Right now, there is currently no known risk with being in the same room at a funeral or visitation service with the body of someone who has died of COVID-19 as long as you continue to maintain a 6 foot distance. That being said, currently, we all must avoid large gatherings and stay at home as much as possible.
answerText: Right now, we don't know of any higher risk due to being in the same room at a funeral or visitation service with the body of someone who has died of COVID-19 as long as you stay 6 feet (2 meters) away. That being said, for now we must all avoid large gatherings and stay at home as much as we can to reduce the spread of COVID-19.

questionOriginal: Am I at risk if I touch someone who has died of COVID-19 after they have passed away?
questionText: Am I at risk if I touch someone who has died of COVID-19 after they have passed away?
answerOriginal: Generally, do not touch the body of someone who has died of COVID-19.   We are still learning how COVID-19 spreads and if a deceased body can transmit the virus. One could get COVID-19 by touching a surface or object that has the virus on it, and then touching their face (like their mouth, nose, or eyes). Activities such as kissing, washing, and shrouding should be avoided before, after, and during the body being prepared. If washing and shrouding the body are important cultural and religious practices, families should work with their community cultural and religious leaders as well as funeral home staff on how to reduce exposure as much as possible. It is recommended that those conducting these activities should wear disposable gloves. If fluid splashing is expected, additional personal protective equipment may be needed (like disposable gowns, goggles, face masks).
answerText: Generally, do not touch the body of someone who has died of COVID-19. We are still learning how COVID-19 spreads and if a deceased body can transmit the virus. One could get COVID-19 by touching a surface or object that has the virus on it, and then touching their face (like their mouth, nose, or eyes).   Try to avoid kissing washing, and shrouding the body. If washing and shrouding the body are important in your culture or religion, work with your community cultural and religious leaders as well as funeral home staff to try to reduce exposure as much as possible. People who conduct these activities should wear disposable gloves. If fluid splashing is expected, more personal protective equipment may be needed, such as disposable gowns, goggles, and face masks.

questionOriginal: What should I do if my family member dies of COVID-19 while overseas?
questionText: What should I do if my family member dies of COVID-19 while overseas?
answerOriginal: If a U.S. citizen dies outside the United States, that person's next of kin or legal representative should notify the US Consular officials at the Department of State. These people are available 24 hours a day, 7 days a week, and provide assistance to US citizens for overseas emergencies.   If the family member, domestic partner, next of kin, or legal representative is in a different country than the deceased person, they should call the Department of State's Office of Overseas Citizens Services in Washington DC, from 8a-5p ET, Mon-Fri, at 888-407-4747 (toll-free) or 202-501-444. For emergency assistance after working hours or on weekends/holidays, call the Department of State switchboard at 202-647-4000 and ask to speak with the Overseas Citizens Services duty officer.   In addition to these steps above, the in-country of closest US embassy can also provide assistance.

questionOriginal: Why might someone blame or avoid individuals and groups because of COVID-19?
questionText: Why might someone blame or avoid individuals and groups because of COVID-19?
answerOriginal: There has been a rise in stigma and hate crimes against Chinese and other Asian Americans, as well as people who were in quarantine. This is due to lack of knowledge around how COVID-19 spreads, a need to blame someone, fears about disease and death, as well as gossip that spreads rumors and myths.  Stigma hurts everyone as it creates more fear and anger towards ordinary people, instead of the disease that is causing the problem, or towards systems that are not supporting people in accessing screening and treatment. Sharing facts about how COVID-19 actually spreads can help stop stigma.

questionOriginal: Is the U.S. food supply safe?
questionText: Is the U.S. food supply safe?
answerOriginal: There is no evidence right now that food or food packaging causes COVID-19.  It is possible that the virus can live on surfaces or objects. It is important to follow the 4 key steps of food safety — clean, separate, cook, and chill. If you are worried about your food or food packaging, wash your hands after touching food, after removing food from the packaging, before you make food for eating and before you eat.
answerText: There is no evidence right now that food or food packaging causes COVID-19.  It is possible that the virus can live on surfaces or objects. It is important to follow the 4 key steps of food safety — clean, separate, cook, and chill. questionOriginal: What are some safe ways to shop for groceries right now?
questionText: What are some safe ways to shop for groceries right now?
answerOriginal: In order to stay safe while shopping, avoid close contact with others and keep six feet of distance with other shoppers. Avoid close contact while shopping include shopping at off-peak hours, wiping down the cart before and after use, and using debit or credit cards to avoid hand-to-hand cash transfers. In areas where grocery delivery is not available, or is stretched to capacity, consider diversifying your procurement channels. In some areas, local farmers and producers may be offering direct purchasing options.
answerText: Like other viruses, it is possible that the virus that causes COVID-19 can stay on surfaces and objects. Here are some tips to reduce risk while grocery shopping:   1. Shop when stores are less busy 2. Disinfect the shopping cart at the grocery store  3. Stay at least 6 feet (2 meters) away from others while shopping 4. Avoid touching your face while shopping  5. While paying, avoid hand-to-hand cash transfers. Wipe down debit or credit cards after using them. 5. Wash your hands as soon as you come home with soap and water  You can also see if delivery services are available in you area. In some areas, you may be able to buy directly from local farmers and producers.  [[Would you like more information about Are there services available to help older adults get groceries?]]

questionOriginal: Should I wash and prepare foods differently once I get them home?
questionText: Should I wash and prepare foods differently once I get them home?
answerOriginal: There is currently no evidence that supports the idea that the virus can be spread through food or food packaging. However, since COVID-19 can survive on hard surfaces for up to 72 hours, shoppers may consider disinfecting food packaging after bringing it home from the store, in addition to common-sense measures like washing hands with soap and water before and after preparing food, and following the Food and Drug Administration’s (FDA) four food safety steps: clean, separate, cook, and chill.  [[Would you like more information about how long COVID-19 lives on surfaces?]]
answerText: Right now there is no evidence that the virus can be spread through food or food packaging. However, since COVID-19 can live on surfaces for up to 72 hours, if you are worried you can disinfect food packaging after bringing it home from the store. You should also follow the usual food safety steps like washing hands with soap and water before and after preparing food, and following the Food and Drug Administration’s (FDA) four food safety steps: clean, separate, cook, and chill. questionText: What food should I eat to help boost my immune system?
answerOriginal: Five core micronutrients—vitamin B6, vitamin C, vitamin E, magnesium, and zinc—play roles in maintaining immune function. questionOriginal: What are some tips for stocking my pantry on a budget?
questionText: What are some tips for stocking my pantry on a budget?
answerOriginal: Here are six practical ways to stretch your dollars at the grocery store.  Make Your Menu: Time permitting, write out a basic meal plan for the week and the groceries you’ll need for it.  Respect the Freezer : frozen fruits and vegetables are a cost-effective source of nutrition.  Play the Sale: Look for discounts, coupons, and sales, especially on store brands, which usually cost less.  Go Big: Buy in bulk when you can (e.g., purchase a whole chicken instead of just chicken breasts). Freeze what you don’t immediately need.  Go Home: If you have time, prepare food yourself instead of buying prepared or frozen meals. Thirty minutes will give you enough time to bring together simple, tasty meals.  Read the Fine Print: Compare unit prices (dollars per pound or per ounce) listed on price tags to find the cheapest brand.  Hold the Steak: Because meat can be a relatively expensive source of protein, look to supplement it with plant-based sources of protein like beans, quinoa, and whole-wheat pasta.  Shop the Season: Off-season produce is almost always more expensive and of inferior quality.

questionOriginal: What should I eat or drink to prevent COVID-19?
questionText: What should I eat or drink to prevent COVID-19?
answerOriginal: Although there is no way to fully prevent getting sick if you are exposed to COVID-19, there are steps you can take that may boost your body's immune system. One way to do this is by having a balanced, healthy diet high in fruits and vegetables. There is no “quick fix” for boosting your immune system, but nutrition is important for immune defense and resistance to disease.
answerText: There is nothing you can eat or drink to prevent COVID-19. The best thing you can do is to eat a balanced, healthy diet high in fruits and vegetables. There is no “quick fix” for boosting your immune system, but nutrition is important to staying healthy.  [[Would you like more information about How can I protect myself and others?]]

questionOriginal: Can drinking alcohol help COVID-19?
questionText: Can drinking alcohol help COVID-19?
answerOriginal: Consuming alcohol will not destroy the virus, and drinking alcohol is likely to increase your health risks if you become infected with the virus. Alcohol (at a concentration of at least 60% by volume) works as a disinfectant on your skin, but does not kill the virus if you drink it. Consumption of alcohol will not kill the virus in the inhaled air, it will not disinfect your mouth and throat, and it will not give you any kind of protection against COVID-19.  If you do drink alcohol, keep your drinking to a minimum and avoid getting drunk or intoxicated.
answerText: Consuming alcohol will not destroy the virus in your mouth or throat. Drinking alcohol could increase your health risks.   You may use alcohol (at a concentration of at least 60%) to clean your skin.   [[Would you like more information about How can I protect myself and others?]]

questionOriginal: Can I go grocery shopping if I have just returned from vacation?
questionText: Can I go grocery shopping if I have just returned from vacation?
answerOriginal: If you believe you have been exposed to COVID-19, or if you are at high risk of symptoms, you should not go to the grocery store.  If you have not been exposed and you do go to the grocery store, experts recommend avoiding close contact with others and keeping six feet of distance with other shoppers. Tips to avoid close contact while shopping include shopping at off-peak hours, wiping down the cart with a disinfectant wipe before and after use, and using debit or credit cards to avoid hand-to-hand cash transfers. You can also wear a cloth face mask to reduce transmission of the virus.  Some areas may be offering grocery deliveries, and you might consider using these services instead of going to the store. In some areas, local farmers and producers may also be offering direct purchasing options.
answerText: If you think you have been exposed to COVID-19, or if you have symptoms, do not go to the grocery store. Depending on where you traveled to, your local or national government may recommend that you quarantine after recent travel. questionOriginal: Should food workers who are ill stay home?
questionText: Should food workers who are ill stay home?
answerOriginal: CDC recommends that employees who have symptoms of acute respiratory illness stay home and not come to work until they are free of fever (100.4° F [37.8° C] or greater using an oral thermometer), signs of a fever, and any other symptoms for at least 24 hours, without the use of fever-reducing or other symptom-altering medicines (e.g. cough suppressants). Employees should notify their supervisor and stay home if they are sick.
answerText: CDC recommends that employees who have symptoms of acute respiratory illness stay home and not come to work until they are free of fever (100.4° F [37.8° C] or greater using an oral thermometer), signs of a fever, and any other symptoms for at least 24 hours, without the use of fever-reducing or other symptom-altering medicines (e.g. cough suppressants). questionOriginal: Since restaurant workers and other service industry employees have ongoing contact with the public, are there any special precautions these workers should take to avoid becoming sick with a respiratory illness, such as wearing masks?
questionText: Since restaurant workers and other service industry employees have ongoing contact with the public, are there any special precautions these workers should take to avoid becoming sick with a respiratory illness, such as wearing masks?
answerOriginal: CDC does not recommend that people who are well wear a face mask to protect themselves from respiratory diseases, including COVID-19. Face masks should be used by people who show symptoms of COVID-19 to help prevent the spread of the disease to others. The use of face masks is also crucial for health workers and people who are taking care of someone with COVID-19 in close settings.  CDC recommends everyday preventive actions for everyone:  Avoid close contact with people who are sick. Avoid touching your eyes, nose, and mouth. Stay home when you are sick. Cover your cough or sneeze with a tissue, then throw the tissue in the trash. Wash your hands often with soap and water for at least 20 seconds, especially after going to the bathroom; before eating; and after blowing your nose, coughing, or sneezing. If soap and water are not readily available, use an alcohol-based hand sanitizer with at least 60% alcohol. Always wash hands with soap and water if hands are visibly dirty.
answerText: CDC does not recommend that people who are well wear a face mask to protect themselves from respiratory diseases, including COVID-19. Face masks should be used by people who show symptoms of COVID-19 to help prevent the spread of the disease to others. The use of face masks is also crucial for health workers and people who are taking care of someone with COVID-19 in close settings. questionOriginal: Do I need to disinfect things I buy like groceries and supplies?
questionText: Do I need to disinfect things I buy like groceries and supplies?
answerOriginal: There is currently no evidence that supports the idea that the virus can be spread through food or food packaging. However, since COVID-19 can survive on hard surfaces for up to 72 hours, shoppers may consider disinfecting food packaging after bringing it home from the store, in addition to common-sense measures like washing hands with soap and water before and after preparing food, and following the Food and Drug Administration’s (FDA) four food safety steps: clean, separate, cook, and chill.  [[Would you like more information about how long COVID-19 lives on surfaces?]]

questionOriginal: What precautions should I take at the supermarket?
questionText: What precautions should I take at the supermarket?
answerOriginal: If you believe you have been exposed to COVID-19, or if you are at high risk of symptoms, you should not go to the grocery store. Depending on where you traveled to, your local or national government may recommend that you stay quarantine for a period after recent travel.

questionOriginal: I Got A Call, Text, Or Email Saying I Could Get Financial Help. Is It Legitimate?
questionText: I Got A Call, Text, Or Email Saying I Could Get Financial Help. Is It Legitimate?
answerOriginal: There have been reports that scammers pretend to be the government. They contact people by robocall, text message, email and other outreach. These scammers say they can get people financial help during the pandemic, and then ask for money or personal information, like your bank account or credit card number. This is scam.

questionOriginal: Should I Worry About Hantavirus?
questionText: Should I Worry About Hantavirus?
answerOriginal: No. The main way hantavirus spreads to people is through infected mice and rats. It is possible to catch hantavirus from another person, but it’s very rare. For more information about hantavirus, visit the CDC’s website.
